{{Infobox non-profit | name = Community Change | image = | type = Nonprofit | founded_date = 1968 | leader_title = President | leader_name = [[Dorian Warren]] | founder = | location = Washington, D.C. | coordinates = | origins = Response to civil rights concerns | key_people = | area_served = Low-income communities across the U.S. | product = | mission =To build the power and capacity of low-income people, especially low-income people of color, to change the policies and institutions that impact their lives. | focus = Jobs and wages, immigration, retirement security, affordable housing, racial justice and barriers to employment for formerly incarcerated individuals | method = | revenue = $37,372,900 (2013)<ref name=guidestar>{{cite web|title=IRS Form 990 2013|url=http://www.guidestar.org/FinDocuments/2013/520/888/2013-520888113-0a77cb1d-9.pdf|publisher=Internal Revenue Service|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = Power from the ground up. | former name = | homepage = | dissolved = | footnotes = | website = {{URL|http://www.communitychange.org}} |logo= Community Change Logo.jpg }} Community Change, formerly The '''Center for Community Change''' ('''CCC'''), is a [[Progressivism in the United States|progressive]] [[community organizing]] group active in the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://billmoyers.com/content/deepak-bhargava/|title=Activists to Watch: Deepak Bhargava|date=October 24, 2013|publisher=Moyers & Company|last1=Dreier|first1=Peter|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> It was founded in 1968 in response to civil rights concerns of the 1960s and to honor [[Robert F. Kennedy]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Change Philanthropy: Candid Stories of Foundations Maximizing Results through Social Justice|date=2009|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9780470522110|page=277|last1=Epstein Korten|first1=Alice}}<!--|accessdate=24 April 2015--></ref><ref name="poverty2">{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of World Poverty, Volume 1|date=2006|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=9781452265186|page=134|last1=Odekon|first1=Mehmet}}<!--|accessdate=24 April 2015--></ref> The organization's stated mission is "to build the power and capacity of low-income people, especially low-income people of color, to change their communities and public policies for the better."<ref>{{cite web|title=Mission|url=http://www.communitychange.org/real-people/mission/|publisher=Center for Community Change|accessdate=13 December 2016}}</ref> Community Change has received funding from the [[Democracy Alliance]] and the [[Tides (organization)#The Advocacy Fund|Tides Advocacy Fund]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/01/29/gop-dark-money_n_6566244.html|title=Groups With Liberal Ties Tapped To Re-Elect The GOP Establishment|date=January 29, 2015|publisher=Huffington Post|last1=Blumenthal|first1=Paul|accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/02/28/democracy-alliance-dumps-_n_1306867.html|title=Democracy Alliance Dumps Progressive Organizations|date=February 28, 2012|publisher=Huffington Post|last1=Grim|first1=Ryan|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> [[File:1536 U Street, N.W..JPG|thumb|CCC headquarters in [[Washington, D.C.]]]]
==Activities== Community Change generally works in low-income areas, especially within communities of color, and attempts to create resident-based groups to work on local issues of concern. The organization sponsors internships and training programs in several areas, including [[community organizing]], [[service learning]], [[union organizing]], electoral engagement, and youth/student organizing.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/12/fashion/12organizer.html?_r=2|title=Community Organizing Never Looked So Good|date=April 10, 2009|publisher=New York Times|last1=Rimer|first1=Sara|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> The organization provides resources for grassroots groups including campaign strategy, funding and social media strategy. In 2004, through the collaboration with immigrant groups, Community Change organized the Fair Immigration Reform Movement that "empowered immigrants to speak out."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stolz|first=Rich|year=2011|title=Lessons For The Future Of Immigration Reform|url=|journal=Social Policy|volume=41.3|pages=4–19|via=Education Source}}</ref> Community Change has helped to create government programs like the [[Community Reinvestment Act]] and the [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program|food stamps program]].<ref name="poverty22">{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of World Poverty, Volume 1|date=2006|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=9781452265186|page=134|last1=Odekon|first1=Mehmet}}<!--|accessdate=24 April 2015--></ref>
The organization seeks to create workplace environments that value family, to guarantee minimum wage, "unlock opportunities in the poorest communities, and increase income taxes for the wealthy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Leong|first=F|last2=Tang|first2=M|year=2016|title=Career Barriers for Chinese Immigrants in the United States|url=|journal=Career Development Quarterly|volume=64.3|pages=259–271|via=Education Source}}</ref>
The Center for Community Change launched the [[Fair Immigration Reform Movement]] (FIRM), an immigration reform movement working for comprehensive immigration reform. FIRM received funding from the [[Open Society Foundations]] and the [[Ford Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/about/programs/us-programs/grantees/center-community-change-fair-immigration-reform-movement|title=Center for Community Change / Fair Immigration Reform Movement|publisher=Open Society Foundations|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fordfoundation.org/grants/grantdetails?grantid=121322|title=Center for Community Change|publisher=Ford Foundation|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.communitychange.org Community Changewebsite] * [http://www.fairimmigration.org/ FIRM website]
{{Immigration to the United States}} {{Center for Community Change|state=expanded}}
[[Category:Community building]] [[Category:Immigrant rights organizations]] [[Category:Civil rights organizations]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1968]] [[Category:Political advocacy groups in the United States]] [[Category:Internship programs]] [[Category:Progressive organizations in the United States]]

page.title: Centre for Studies on Inclusive Education

revision.text:
The '''Centre for Studies on Inclusive Education''' ('''CSIE''') is an independent centre and registered charity based in the [[United Kingdom]] which aims to promote [[Inclusive classroom|inclusion]] in education. As part of their work, they publish booklets on inclusive practice, and summaries of laws related to inclusion.
==See also==
* [[Special education in the United Kingdom]] * [[Dyslexia support in the United Kingdom]]
==External links== *[http://www.csie.org.uk/ CSIE official website] *[http://www.csie.org.uk/resources/ CSIE resources]
<!-- Categories listed below -->
{{DEFAULTSORT:Centre For Studies On Inclusive Education}} [[Category:Education in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Special education]] [[Category:Dyslexia]]
{{UK-edu-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |image= |name=Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) |founded_date=2004 |location= |origins= |key_people= |area_served=International |focus=Computer Science Education |revenue= |endowment= |owner= |Non-profit_slogan= |former name={{URL|http://www.csta.acm.org/}} |homepage={{URL|http://www.csteachers.org/}} }} The '''Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA)''' is a [[professional association]] whose mission to “empower, engage and advocate for K-12 CS teachers worldwide.” It supports and encourages [[education]] in the field of [[computer science]] and related areas. Started in 2004, CSTA supports computer science education in [[elementary school]]s, [[middle school]]s, [[high school]]s, [[higher education]], and [[industry]].<ref name="csta_about">{{cite web|title=Computer Science Teachers - About |url=http://www.csteachers.org/?About|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref>
==Awards== Together with the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] (ACM), the CSTA offers the '''ACM/CSTA Cutler-Bell Prize in High School Computing'''. The award provides four $10,000 scholarships to each of four winners along with travel to a reception each February.<ref name="cbprize">{{cite web|title=The ACM/CSTA Cutler-Bell Prize in High School Computing|url=http://www.newtechnetwork.org/services/resources/acmcsta-cutler-bell-prize-high-school-computing|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref>
==Computer Science Education Standards== CSTA publishes a set of recommended Computer Science Standards for kindergarten through high school.<ref name="csstds">{{cite web|title=Computer Science Education Standards|url=https://csta.acm.org/Curriculum/sub/CurrFiles/CSTA_K-12_CSS.pdf|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref> CSTA the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] publish an interactive State-By-State map showing the degree to which the recommended computer science standards have been included in the state educational standards.<ref name="stateadoption">{{cite web|title=Running on Empty |url=http://runningonempty.acm.org/roemap.html|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref>
CSTA recommendations for computer science education include beginning introductory lessons as early as kindergarten.<ref name="cert">{{cite web|title=Computer Science Teacher Certification |url=http://www.teaching-certification.com/computer-science-teacher-certification.html|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref> A recent report by [[Association for Computing Machinery]] and the ''CSTA, Running on Empty: The Failure to Teach K-12 Computer Science in the Digital Age'', found that in the [[United States]], most high schools count computer science as an elective and most secondary schools have few educational standards related to computer science.<ref name="paradox">{{cite web|title=Education's Most Startling Paradox: K-12 Computer Science Education Declines |url=http://www.acm.org/press-room/news-releases/2010/education-paradox/|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref>
==Code.org Advocacy Coalition== CSTA is one of the participating organizations in the '''Code.org Advocacy Coalition''' (previously called Computing in the Core (CinC)).<ref name="coalition">{{cite web|url=https://code.org/computing-in-the-core|title=Computing in the Core (CinC)|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref> The Code.org Advocacy Coalition is a group of organizations that works on public outreach and advocacy to encourage additional support for computer science in the core curriculum and includes members such as [[Microsoft]], [[Google]], [[Facebook]], [[Anita Borg Institute for Women and Technology]], [[Computing Research Association]], and others.<ref name="advocacy">{{cite web|title=Code.org Advocacy Coalition|url=https://code.org/advocacy|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref>
==Chapters== CSTA has more than 50 chapters in the [[United States]]<ref name="chapters">{{cite web|title=CSTA Chapters |url=https://csta.acm.org/About/sub/CSTAChapters.html|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref> and international affiliates in [[Israel]], [[New Zealand]], and the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name="affiliates">{{cite web|url=https://csta.acm.org/About/sub/Affiliates.html|title=CSTA Affiliates|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref>
==Newsletters== CSTA publishes a bi-monthly newsletter, the CSTA Voice, that highlights issues related to computer science education.<ref>[http://www.csta.acm.org/Communications/sub/CSTAVoice.html CSTA Voice]</ref>
==Governance== The 2017–2018 CSTA Board of Directors consists of: * Fred Martin, Chair * Dave Reed, Past Chair * David Benedetto, At-Large Representative * Doug Bergman, 9-12 Teacher Representative * Miles Berry, International Representative * Michelle Lagos, At-Large Representative * Anthony Owen, State Department Representative * Jane Prey, ACM Representative * Jennifer Rosato, Teacher Education Representative * Vicky Sedgwick, K-8 Teacher Representative * Vandana Sikka, Partner Representative * Bobby Schnabel, Partner Representative * Fran Trees, Chapter Liaison * Bryan Twarek, School District Representative * Chinma Uche, 9-12 Teacher Representative
CSTA Committees include: {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Educational assessment|Assessment]] Task Force * [[Certification]] and [[Learning standards|Standards]] * [[Chapters]] Task Force * Computational Thinking Task Force * [[Curriculum]] * [[Educational equity|Equity]] * [[Funding]] Development * [[Governance]] * [[International]] * K-8 Task Force (Kindergarten through 8th grade) * Nominations and Elections * [[Professional Development]] * [[Publications]] and [[Communication]]s * [[Research]] }}
==See also== {{Portal|Computer Science|Computing|Education}} * [[Association for Computing Machinery]] * [[Computer science]] * [[Education]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.csteachers.org/ New official website (in progress)] * [https://csta.acm.org/ Official website] * [http://www.acm.org/ Association for Computing Machinery] * [https://csedweek.org/ Computer Science Education Week] * [http://awards.acm.org/cutler-bell/ ACM/CSTA Cutler-Bell Prize in High School Computing]
{{Authority control}}

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text: {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox website | name = DBLP | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | url = {{Official URL}} | commercial = No | type = [[Online database]] | registration = None | owner = [[University of Trier]] | author = [[Michael Ley]] | editor = [[Leibniz Center for Informatics]] | launch date = 1993 | content_licence = | current status = | revenue = }} '''DBLP''' is a [[computer science]] [[bibliography]] website. Starting in 1993 at the [[University of Trier]], [[Germany]], it grew from a small collection of HTML files{{cite conference|last1=Ley |first1=Michael |authorlink1=Michael Ley |title=DBLP: Some Lessons Learned |url=https://dblp.org/xml/docu/dblpxml.pdf |event=[[VLDB conference|VLDB]] |work=Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment |volume=2 |issue=2 |date=2009 |pages=1493–1500 |citeseerx=10.1.1.151.3018 |issn=2150-8097 |doi=10.14778/1687553.1687577 |accessdate=2018-03-13}} and became an organization hosting a [[database]] and [[logic programming]] bibliography site. DBLP listed more than 3.66 million journal articles, conference papers, and other publications on computer science in July 2016, up from about 14,000 in 1995.{{cite web |url=https://dblp.org/statistics/recordsindblp |title=Records in DBLP |department=Statistics |website=DBLP |accessdate=2018-03-13}} All important journals on computer science are tracked. Proceedings papers of many conferences are also tracked. It is mirrored at three sites across the [[Internet]].{{cite web |title=Computer science bibliography |url=https://dblp.org/ |website=DBLP |accessdate=2018-03-13}}{{cite journal |last=Ley |first=Michael |authorlink1=Michael Ley |title=The DBLP Computer Science Bibliography: Evolution, Research Issues, Perspectives |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j6ptCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1 |doi=10.1007/3-540-45735-6_1 |pages=481–486 |publisher=Springer-Verlag |series=[[Lecture Notes in Computer Science|LNCS]] |work=String Processing and Information Retrieval |volume=2000 |date=2002 |accessdate=2018-05-01}}{{cite journal |last1=Petricek |first1=Vaclav |last2=Cox |first2=Ingemar J. |last3=Han |first3=Hui |last4=Councill |first4=Isaac G. |last5=Giles |first5=C. Lee |title=A Comparison of On-Line Computer Science Citation Databases |doi=10.1007/11551362_39 |pages=438–449 |publisher=Springer-Verlag |series=[[Lecture Notes in Computer Science|LNCS]] |work=Research and Advanced Technology for Digital Libraries |volume=3652 |date=2005 |arxiv=cs/0703043 }} For his work on maintaining DBLP, [[Michael Ley]] received an award from the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] and the VLDB Endowment Special Recognition Award in 1997. ''DBLP'' originally stood for ''DataBase systems and Logic Programming''. As a [[backronym]], it has been taken to stand for ''Digital Bibliography & Library Project'';{{cite journal |last1=Ley |first1=Michael |authorlink1=Michael Ley |last2=Reuther |first2=Patrick |title=Maintaining an Online Bibliographical Database: the Problem of Data Quality. |url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/7c21/813827533edf65744772d471433cba0c15a6.pdf |journal=EGC, ser. Revue des Nouvelles Technologies de l’Information |volume=RNTI-E-6 |date=2006 |pages=5–10 |citeseerx=10.1.1.67.6180 |accessdate=2018-05-01}} however, it is now preferred that the acronym be simply a name, hence the new title "The DBLP Computer Science Bibliography".{{cite web |title=What is the meaning of the acronym dblp? |url=https://dblp.org/faq/What+is+the+meaning+of+the+acronym+dblp |department=FAQ |website=DBLP |accessdate=2018-03-13}} Users of dblp remain unaffected by some additional attributes in the DTD {{as of|2016|February|lc=y}}, which are meant to support future versions of the data file. Thus consumers of the raw dblp.xml file should update their local dblp.dtd file, according to the notice on the home page, {{as of|2016|February|lc=y}}.{{cite web |date=February 29, 2016 |title=Small modifications to dblp's XML format |url=https://dblp.org/news/2016 |department=News |website=DBLP |accessdate=2018-03-13}} ==DBL-Browser== {{Infobox software |name = DBL-Browser |developer = Alexander Weber |released = {{Start date and age|2005}} |latest release version = 2.0b |latest release date = {{release date and age|2006|09|06}} |programming language = [[Java (programming language)|Java]] |operating_system = [[Unix]] |genre = [[XML]] |license = [[GNU General Public License|GPL]] |website = dbis.uni-trier.de/DBL-Browser (offline) }} ''DBL-Browser'' (''Digital Bibliographic Library Browser'') is a utility for browsing the DBLP website. The browser was written by Alexander Weber in 2005 at the [[University of Trier]]. It was designed for use off-line in reading the DBLP, which consisted of 696,000 bibliographic entries in 2005 (and in 2015 has more than 2.9 million). DBL-Browser is [[GPL]] [[software]], available for download from [[SourceForge]]. It uses the [[XML]] [[Document Type Definition|DTD]]. Written in [[Java programming language]], this code shows the bibliographic entry in several types of screens, ranging from graphics to text: *Author page *Article page *Table of contents *Related conferences / journals *Related authors (graphic representation of relationships) *Trend analysis (graphics histogram) DBLP is similar to the bibliographic portion of [[arxiv.org]] which also links to articles. DBL-Browser provides a means to view some of the associated computer science articles. ==See also== *[[Association for Computational Linguistics]] *[[CiteSeerX]] *[[CogPrints]] *[[Google Scholar]] *[[Live Search Academic]] *[[The Collection of Computer Science Bibliographies]] *[[Dagstuhl]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikidata property|P2456}} * {{Official website}} ** [https://dblp.org/search/ CompleteSearch DBLP] provides a fast search-as-you-type interface to DBLP, as well as faceted search. It is maintained by [[Hannah Bast]] and synchronized twice daily with the DBLP database. Since December 2007, the search functionality is embedded into each DBLP author page (via [[Javascript]]). * {{cite web |title=LZI+DBLP |url=https://www.dagstuhl.de/en/about-dagstuhl/projects/lzi-dblp/ |work=[[Schloss Dagstuhl]] |publisher=[[Leibniz Center for Informatics]] |accessdate=2017-02-11}} * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222024555/http://dbis.uni-trier.de/DBL-Browser/ |title=DBL-Browser}} * [http://dblp.L3S.de FacetedDBLP] provides a faceted search interface to DBLP, synchronized once per week with the DBLP database. In addition to common facets such as year, author, or venues, it contains a topic-based facet summarizing and characterizing the current result set based on the author keywords for individual publications. For the DBLP data, FacetedDBLP also provides an [[Resource Description Framework|RDF]] dump (using [http://www4.wiwiss.fu-berlin.de/bizer/d2r-server/ D2R server] technology) as well as an [[SQL]] dump based on the underlying mysql database. * [http://www.confsearch.org confsearch] Conference search engine and calendar based on DBLP. * [http://dblp.cloudmining.net/ CloudMining DBLP] is another faceted search solution with different visualizations. [[Category:Bibliographic databases and indexes]] [[Category:Digital library projects]] [[Category:Bibliographic databases in computer science]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 1993]] [[Category:1993 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:University of Trier]]

{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} The '''Defence Technical Undergraduate Scheme (DTUS)''' is a university sponsorship programme for students who want to join the [[Royal Navy]], [[British Army]], [[Royal Air Force]] or [[DESG|Engineering and Science branch]] of the Ministry of Defence (MOD) Civil Service as technical officers after they graduate; Army sponsored students are destined for either the [[Royal Corps of Signals]], [[Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers]], [[Royal Engineers]] or [[The Royal Logistic Corps]]. Students on the scheme are sponsored by the MOD to study accredited technical degree programmes.
==Background==
The DTUS was created following the 2001 [[Defence Training Review]] (DTR). The DTR identified that the [[Royal Navy]], [[British Army]], [[Royal Air Force]] and [[DESG|MOD Civil Service]] had difficulties in recruiting engineering officers. As a result, DTUS was created whereby sponsored students study at eleven partner universities ([[Aston University|Aston]], Birmingham, Cambridge, Imperial College, Loughborough, Newcastle, Northumbria, Portsmouth, Southampton and Strathclyde)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dsfc.ac.uk/University-and-Degree-Choices}}</ref>. DTUS is expected to reach and maintain a strength of eight hundred students in September 2016.
==Aim==
The aim of DTUS is ‘to educate and develop selected individuals to prepare them for further training and careers as engineer or technical officers in the Armed Forces or as graduate entrants to the MOD Civil Service’.<ref>DEFAC/DCMT/20/65/20</ref>
==Support units==
DTUS students are able to choose the partner university they wish to study at and select a degree course that has been approved by their sponsoring service. Whilst at their partner university, all students belong to a support unit who are responsible for their leadership development, mentorship and administration. They also closely monitor academic progress, to that end the commanding officer of each support unit has visiting lecturer status at their university to support this. There are four support units throughout the UK:
*'''Taurus Squadron'''<ref>{{cite web|title=DTOESS – Taurus Squadron|url=http://www.da.mod.uk/dtoees/taurus-squadron|publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|MoD]]}}</ref> based in [[Birmingham]] supports students at [[Aston University]]<ref>[http://www1.aston.ac.uk/eas/undergraduate/dtus/ Aston University – School of Engineering & Applied Science – DTUS]</ref> and the [[University of Birmingham]]. It also administers students at the [[University of Oxford]]. *'''Thunderer Squadron'''<ref>{{cite web|title=DTOESS – Thunderer Squadron|url=http://www.da.mod.uk/dtoees/thunderer-squadron|publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|MoD]]}}</ref> based in [[Southampton]] supports students at the [[University of Southampton]] as well as the [[University of Portsmouth]]. It also administers students at [[Imperial College London]]. *'''Trojan Squadron'''<ref>{{cite web|title=DTOESS – Trojan Squadron|url=http://www.da.mod.uk/dtoees/trojan-squadron|publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|MoD]]}}</ref> based in [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] supports students at [[Newcastle University|Newcastle]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Armed Services choose Newcastle University to train Officers of the future |url=http://www.ncl.ac.uk/press.office/press.release/item/1024492050 |publisher=[[Newcastle University]] |date=19 June 2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120711015954/http://www.ncl.ac.uk/press.office/press.release/item/1024492050 |archivedate=11 July 2012 |df= }}</ref> and [[Northumbria University|Northumbria]] universities. It administers students at the [[University of Strathclyde]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Strathclyde joins the Defence Technical Undergraduate Scheme|url=http://www.strath.ac.uk/mec/news|date=May 2014}}</ref> *'''Typhoon Squadron'''<ref>{{cite web|title=DTOESS – Typhoon Squadron|url=http://www.da.mod.uk/dtoees/typhoon-squadron|publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|MoD]]}}</ref> based in [[Loughborough]] supports students at [[Loughborough University]]. It also administers students at [[Cambridge university]].
===Staffing===
Each support unit is commanded by the same equivalent rank from each service; Taurus and Trojan Squadrons – [[lieutenant colonel]], Thunderer Squadron – [[commander]] and Typhoon Squadron – [[Wing Commander (rank)|wing commander]]. There are a Royal Navy lieutenant, an Army [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]] and a Royal Air Force [[flight lieutenant]] working as training officers in each squadron. Additionally at each squadron there is an SNCO and a civilian administrator. Assisting at each squadron are in-service degree officers who are commissioned officers reading for a degree at the partner university.
==Students==
Each military sponsored student is a member of their respective service reserve forces (and holds a Service number) and holds the rank of [[officer cadet]] ([[midshipman]] for Royal Navy-sponsored students). All students receive an annual bursary and also receive training pay for the activities that they participate in. In return, students are expected to remain physically fit (pass an annual fitness assessment known as a PFA), advance each academic year and serve for a minimum of three years in the Armed Forces or MOD Civil Service after graduating from Initial Officer Training (IOT).
The majority of entrants on the DTUS are graduates of the [[Welbeck College|Defence Sixth Form College (Welbeck)]] near [[Woodhouse, Leicestershire]]. However, students studying or scheduled to study an approved degree at either of the partner universities may also apply to join the scheme as a Direct Entrant (DE)
==See also== *[[University Royal Naval Unit]] *[[Officers' Training Corps]] *[[University Air Squadron]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.da.mod.uk/Colleges-Business-Units/6th-Form-DTUS Official Site] *[http://www.desg.mod.uk/downloads/DTUS_fact_sheet.pdf MOD Defence Technical Undergraduate Scheme Factsheet]
{{Defence Academy of the United Kingdom}}

revision.comment: /* Impact and current status */the work's name is "The New York Times"
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=July 2014}} '''[[Second Life]]''' is used as a platform for education by many institutions, such as colleges, universities, libraries and government entities.
==Impact and current status== There are over one hundred regions used for educational purposes covering subjects such as chemistry<ref>{{cite web|url=http://slusage.com/chemistry.asp |title=Chemistry in Second Life |publisher=Slusage.com |date= |accessdate=2010-02-19}}</ref> and English.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.languagelab.com/ |title=A Real School in Second Life |publisher=Languagelab.com |date= |accessdate=2010-02-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://literaturealive.blogspot.com/ |title=English Literature in Second Life |publisher=Literaturealive.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2010-02-19}}</ref> Instructors and researchers in Second Life favor it because it is more personal than traditional distance learning.<ref>{{cite news |first=Christine |last=Lagorio |title=The Ultimate Distance Learning |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/07/education/edlife/07innovation.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2007-01-07 |accessdate = 2007-02-14 }}</ref> Research published in 2007 suggested that development, teaching and/or learning activities using Second Life were present in over 80 percent of UK universities.<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Kirriemuir |title=Snapshots of Second Life use in UK HE and FE|url=http://www.eduserv.org.uk/foundation/studies/slsnapshots |work=[[Eduserv Foundation]] |date=2007-05-05 |accessdate = 2008-08-04 }}</ref> As of 2008, at least 300 universities around the world teach courses or conduct research in SL.<ref>{{cite news |first=Patrick |last=Michels |title=Universities Use Second Life to Teach Complex Concepts|url=http://www.govtech.com/gt/252550 |work=[[Government Technology]] |date=2008-02-16 |accessdate = 2008-11-15 }}</ref> New educational institutions have also emerged that operate exclusively within Second Life,<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Erard |title=A Boon to Second Life Language Schools|url=http://www.technologyreview.com/Infotech/18510/?a=f |work=[[Education]] |date=2007-04-10 |accessdate = 2008-11-19 }}</ref> taking advantage of the platform to deliver content to a worldwide audience at low cost.<ref>{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Cowan |title=The 'second wave' of Second Life|url=http://uk.reuters.com/news/video?videoId=92549&videoChannel=6 |work=[[News]] |date=2008-10-10 |accessdate = 2008-11-19 }}</ref>
Due to the announced closure of [[Teen Second Life]] in 2010-2011, many derivative [[OpenSimulator]] grids have been established for hosting educational projects.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}
==Structure== ''Info Islands'' uses library programming sponsored by the Illinois' [[Alliance Library System]] and OPAL currently offered online to librarians and library users within Second Life. Another virtual continent called ''[[SciLands]]'' is devoted to science and technology education. While initially centered on the [http://slispaceflightmuseum.org/drupal/ International Spaceflight Museum], it now hosts a number of organizations including [[NASA]], [[NOAA]], [[NIH]], [[JPL]], [[NPR]], [[National Physical Laboratory, UK]], and a host of other government agencies, universities, and museums. In December 2008, the United States [[Air Force]] launched MyBase, a Second Life island overseen by the Air Education and Training Command.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123126243 |title=AETC opens virtual doors to MyBase |publisher=Af.mil |date= |accessdate=2009-03-08}}</ref>
Second Life's usefulness as a platform for pre-[[K–12 (education)|K–12]] education is limited due to the age restrictions on the main grid and the difficulties of collaborating among various educational projects on the teen grid. New approaches to fostering collaboration on the teen grid, such as the ''Virtual World Campus'', offer some hope of overcoming some of these obstacles. For now, however, the primary utility of Second Life for pre-K–12 education is in the education and professional development of teachers and school librarians. Still, K–12 educators use Second Life to meet each other and to create objects and structures that help them develop curriculum, as [[EnergyTeachers.org]] does with its Sustainability Energy Science Lab.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}
==Educational disciplines==
===Accounting=== [[Ernst & Young]] made a $500,000 donation to the [[North Carolina State University]] Accounting Department to implement Second Life into the curriculum in 2009.<ref name=TBJ_2ndLife>{{cite web |author=Staff |title=Ernst & Young grants money to NCSU for Second Life |date=Feb 2, 2009 |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2009/02/02/daily20.html |accessdate=2016-04-11 }}</ref> This funding was utilized by [[Frank A Buckless]] along with Mr. Scott Showalter and Dr. Kathy Krawczyk to create a virtual warehouse for their students to audit.<ref name=Khanna2016>{{cite web |author=Khanna, Samiha |date=2016-02-09 |title= Research Spotlight: Virtual reality makes auditing come to life: Using Second Life in the classroom gives students hands-on experience. |publisher=[[American Institute of Certified Public Accountants]] |url=https://www.aicpa.org/interestareas/accountingeducation/newsandpublications/pages/virtual-reality-in-accounting-education.aspx |accessdate=2016-04-11 }}</ref><ref name=2ndLifeCPAjournal>{{cite journal |author1=Buckless, Frank |author2=Krawczyk, Kathy |author3=Showalter, Scott. |title=Accounting Education in the Second Life World |journal=The CPA Journal |date=Mar 2012 |pages=65–71 |url=http://search.proquest.com/openview/fef292bdef74d7e655ed9eee6a9a5a23/1?pq-origsite=gscholar |accessdate=2016-04-11 }}</ref> The data collected from this study showed that students improved “inventory observation knowledge, interviewing, audit documentation, critical thinking, and group work skills”.<ref name="BucklessKrawczyk2014">{{cite journal|last1=Buckless|first1=Frank A.|last2=Krawczyk|first2=Kathy|last3=Showalter|first3=D. Scott|title=Using Virtual Worlds to Simulate Real-World Audit Procedures|journal=Issues in Accounting Education|volume=29|issue=3|year=2014|pages=389–417|issn=0739-3172|doi=10.2308/iace-50785}}</ref><ref name="Wilson2014">{{cite book|author=Richard M.S. Wilson|title=The Routledge Companion to Accounting Education|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kC1zAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA273|date=29 April 2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-51151-8|pages=273–}}</ref> This project follows incorporation of cost and financial accounting activities in virtual environments.<ref name="RennieMorrison2013">{{cite book|author1=Frank Rennie|author2=Tara Morrison|title=E-Learning and Social Networking Handbook: Resources for Higher Education|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m6LbCgAAQBAJ|date=4 January 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-32018-7|page=118}}</ref>
===Language=== {{Main article|Virtual World Language Learning}} Language learning is the most widespread type of education in virtual worlds,<ref>{{cite news |title=8D Taps Language Learners, Bots, Microtransactions |url=http://www.virtualworldsnews.com/2009/05/out-of-stealth-8d-taps-language-learners-bots-microtransactions.html |work=Virtual World News |date=2009-05-29 |accessdate=2009-06-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090601072358/http://www.virtualworldsnews.com/2009/05/out-of-stealth-8d-taps-language-learners-bots-microtransactions.html |archivedate=2009-06-01 |df= }}</ref> with many universities, mainstream language institutes and private language schools using 3D virtual environments to support language learning.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}
===Nursing=== Second life has been utilized in nursing education to provide meaningful care experience without risk to patients.<ref name="TiffanyHoglund2014">{{cite journal|last1=Tiffany|first1=Jone|last2=Hoglund|first2=Barbara A.|title=Teaching/Learning in Second Life: Perspectives of Future Nurse-Educators|journal=Clinical Simulation in Nursing|volume=10|issue=1|year=2014|pages=e19–e24|issn=1876-1399|doi=10.1016/j.ecns.2013.06.006}}</ref>
Dr. Constance M. Johnson received a [[NIH Exploratory/Developmental Research Grant Award|R21]] award to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of using a virtual environment to provide self-management interventions to people with type 2 diabetes.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Vorderstrasse A, Shaw RJ, Blascovich J, Johnson CM |title=A theoretical framework for a virtual diabetes self-management community intervention |journal=West J Nurs Res |volume=36 |issue=9 |pages=1222–37 |year=2014 |pmid=24451083 |pmc=4296559 |doi=10.1177/0193945913518993 |url=}}</ref>
Dr. Estelle Codier (University of Hawaii) received a National League for Nursing grant award to study learning outcomes for student nurses in Second Life. Her book, "Teaching Healthcare in Virtual Space: Best Practices for Educators in Multi-User Virtual Environments" provides an outline of the pedagogical basis for teaching in MUVE, as well as chapters on development of MUVE teaching skills and others on how to develop learning activities in Second Life. July, 2016.
==Controversy==
===Ban of educational institution=== [[File:Woodbury University SL Campus 100411.jpg|thumb|[[Woodbury University]]'s virtual campus]]
Second Life has twice, in 2007 and 2010, banned a California educational institution, [[Woodbury University]], from having a representation within Second Life. On 20 April 2010 four simulators belonging to the university were deleted and the accounts of several students and professors terminated, according to ''[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]''. Dr. Edward Clift, the dean of Woodbury University's School of Media, Culture and Design, stated that their campus "was a living, breathing campus in Second Life", that included educational spaces designed mostly by students, including a mock representation of the former [[Soviet Union]] and a replica of the [[Berlin Wall]]. As Dr. Clift told ''The Chronicle of Higher Education'', the virtual campus did not "conform to what Linden Lab wanted a campus to be".<ref>{{cite news |title= The Death of a Virtual Campus |author=Andrea L. Foster |newspaper= [[The Chronicle of Higher Education]] |date= July 13, 2007 |url=http://chronicle.com/article/The-Death-of-a-Virtual-Campus/12732 }}</ref><ref name="Chronicle-2010">{{cite news |title= Woodbury U. Banned From Second Life, Again |author=Jeff Young |newspaper= [[The Chronicle of Higher Education]] |date= April 21, 2010 |url=http://chronicle.com/blogPost/Woodbury-U-Banned-From-Second/23352/ }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= California College Loses Second Life for a Second Time |author=Jeff Greer |newspaper= [[U.S. News & World Report]] |date= April 22, 2010 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/paper-trail/2010/04/22/california-college-loses-second-life-for-a-second-time.html }}</ref> Linden Lab said their decision to ban Woodbury University in April 2010 was "based on historical and recent events that constitute a breach of the Second Life community standards and terms of service."<ref name="Chronicle-2010" />
The university has since moved to a separate, dedicated [[OpenSimulator]] grid.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}
==Second Life Educators==
=== Annabeth Robinson ===
: Main Article: ''[[Annabeth Robinson]]''
Annabeth Robinson is a Second Life performer and educator who lectures at [[Leeds College of Art]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Hiles|first=J|title=Blended Realities: A Virtual Tour of Education in Second Life|url=http://etec.hawaii.edu/proceedings/2007/calongne.pdf|accessdate=30 October 2011}}</ref> She develops tools and techniques for improving virtual environment education including the widely used MetaLab Whiteboard. '<ref>{{cite web|last=Kemp|first=J|title=Second Life Education Workshop 2007|citeseerx = 10.1.1.129.6374|publisher=Second Life Community Convention|accessdate=28 October 2011}}</ref>
=== Robin Winter ===
Robin Winter aka Shukran Fahid / Shukran Serendipity has worked with several organisations including Immersive Education and Imperial College to produce a number of training programmes for schools, universities, the NHS and the Ministry of Defense using both Second Life and Open Sim. Currently the CEO of Warm Winter Arts, he is bringing virtualisation into mobile applications and biological sciences.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}
<big>'''Estelle Codier'''</big>
Dr. Estelle Codier is an Associate Professor at the University of Hawaii who has supervised over 500 health care learning activities in Second Life. Her book, "Teaching Healthcare in Second Life: Best Practices for Educators in Multi User Virtual Environments" outlines a pedagogical basis for teaching in Second Life and provides guidelines for developing teaching skills and learning activities in MUVE. July, 2016
===Jessica Gayle===
==References== {{reflist}} Codier, Estelle( 2016) Teaching Healthcare in Virtual Space: Best Practices for Educators in Multi-User Virtual Environments. University of Hawaii Press: Honolulu.{{ISBN|978-0-8248-5800-1}}
==External links== {{commons category}} * [http://education.secondlife.com Second Life Education portal] {{Second Life}}
[[Category:Distance education]] [[Category:Second Life]]

{{globalize/US|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox disease | Name = Emotional and behavioral disorders with onset usually occurring in childhood and adolescence | Image = | Caption = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|F|90||f|90}}–{{ICD10|F|98||f|90}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|312}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | DiseasesDB = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = }} '''Emotional and behavioral disorders''' ('''EBD'''; also known as '''behavioural and emotional disorders''' ([[ICD-10]]);<ref name="ICD-10-web-EN">{{cite web |author=[[World Health Organization]] |url=http://apps.who.int/classifications/icd10/browse/2016/en#/F90 |title=International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems 10th Revision (ICD-10): Behavioural and emotional disorders with onset usually occurring in childhood and adolescence (F90–F98) |date=2016 |access-date=2 November 2018}}</ref><ref name="ICD-10-Clinical">{{cite book |author=[[World Health Organization]] |url=http://www.who.int/classifications/icd/en/bluebook.pdf |title=The ICD-10 Classification of Mental and Behavioural Disorders. Clinical descriptions and diagnostic guidelines |place=[[Geneva]] |page=40}}</ref> sometimes called '''emotional disturbance''' or '''serious emotional disturbance''') refer to a disability classification used in educational settings that allows educational institutions to provide [[special education]] and related services to students that have poor social or academic adjustment that cannot be better explained by biological abnormalities or a [[developmental disability]].
The classification is often given to students, after conducting a Functional Behavior Analysis. These students need individualized [[classroom management|behavior supports]] such as a Behavior Intervention Plan, to receive a [[free and appropriate public education]]. They would not be eligible for an [[individualized education program]] under another disability category of the [[Individuals with Disabilities Education Act]] (IDEA).
==Criteria== The IDEA requires that a student must exhibit one or more of the following characteristics over a long duration, and to a marked degree that adversely affects their educational performance, to receive an EBD classification:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parentcenterhub.org/repository/categories/|title=Categories of Disability Under IDEA|work=parentcenterhub.org|accessdate=22 October 2015}}</ref> * Difficulty to learn that cannot be explained by intellectual, sensory, or health factors. * Difficulty to build or maintain satisfactory interpersonal relationships with peers and teachers. * Inappropriate types of behavior (acting out against self or others) or feelings (expresses the need to harm self or others, low self-worth, etc.) under normal circumstances. * A general pervasive mood of unhappiness or depression. * A tendency to develop physical symptoms or fears associated with personal or school problems.
The term "EBD" includes students diagnosed with [[schizophrenia]], but does not apply to students who are "socially maladjusted", unless it is determined that they also meet the criteria for an EBD classification.
===Criticisms=== Providing or failing to provide an EBD classification to a student may be controversial, as the [[Individuals with Disabilities Education Act|IDEA]] does not clarify which children would be considered "socially maladjusted", but ineligible for an [[individualized education program]] under an EBD classification. Some states do not allow students with a psychiatric diagnosis of [[conduct disorder]] to receive additional educational services under an EBD classification,<ref name="cecp.air.org">{{cite web |url=http://cecp.air.org/resources/20th/eligchar.asp/ |title=Students with Emotional Disturbance: Eligibility and Characteristics |work=cecp.air.org |accessdate=22 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018115029/http://cecp.air.org/resources/20th/eligchar.asp |archivedate=18 October 2015 |df= }}</ref> although many students with an EBD classification do meet the diagnostic criteria for various [[disruptive behavior disorder]]s, including [[attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder]] (ADHD), [[oppositional defiant disorder]] (ODD), or [[conduct disorder]] (CD).<ref name="cecp.air.org"/> Additionally, students considered "socially maladjusted", but ineligible for an EBD classification (i.e., students diagnosed with [[conduct disorder]]), often receive better educational services in special education classrooms or alternative schools with high structure, clear rules, and consistent consequences,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.behavior-consultant.com/social.htm|title=Social Maladjustment|work=behavior-consultant.com|accessdate=22 October 2015}}</ref> which they would not receive in general education settings. The ambiguous guidelines for determining what students are "socially maladjusted", but without EBD, may cause many students that would benefit from special education services to receive less effective educational services.
==Student characteristics== Students with EBD are a diverse population, and have a wide range of intellectual and academic abilities. Males, African-Americans, and economically disadvantaged students are overrepresented in the EBD population, and students with EBD are more likely to live in single-parent homes, foster homes, or other non-traditional living situations.<ref name="cecp.air.org"/> They also tend to have low rates of positive social interactions with students and peers in instructional contexts,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wehby|first1=Joseph|last2=Symons|first2=F.|last3=Shores|first3=R. E.|title=A descriptive analysis of aggressive behavior in classrooms for children with emotional and behavioral disorders|journal=Behavioral Disorders|date=1995|volume=20|pages=87–105}}</ref> and many have one or more comorbid psychiatric diagnoses.<ref name="cecp.air.org"/> Students with EBD are often categorized as [[internalizing disorder|"internalizers"]] (e.g., have poor [[self-esteem]], or are diagnosed with an [[anxiety disorder]] or [[mood disorder]]) or [[Emotional and behavioral disorders#Internalizing and externalizing behavior|"externalizers"]] (e.g., disrupt classroom instruction, or are diagnosed with [[disruptive behavior disorders]] such as [[oppositional defiant disorder]] and [[conduct disorder]]). Male students may be overrepresented in the EBD population because they tend to exhibit disruptive externalizing behavior that interferes with classroom instruction, whereas females more commonly exhibit internalizing behavior that does not interfere with classroom instruction;<ref name="cecp.air.org"/> thus, teachers may refer males for special education services more often than females. Students with EBD are also at an increased risk for [[learning disabilities]], [[school dropout]], [[substance abuse]], and [[juvenile delinquency]].<ref name="cecp.air.org"/>
==Internalizing and externalizing behavior== A person with EBD with [[internalizing disorder|"internalizing" behavior]] may have poor [[self-esteem]], suffer from [[depression (mood)|depression]], experience [[anhedonia|loss of interest]] in social, academic, and other life activities, and may exhibit [[non-suicidal self-injury]] or [[substance abuse]]. Students with internalizing behavior may also have a diagnosis of [[separation anxiety]] or another [[anxiety disorder]], [[post-traumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD), [[specific phobia|specific]] or [[social phobia]], [[obsessive–compulsive disorder]] (OCD), [[panic disorder]], and/or an [[eating disorder]]. Some research suggests students with EBD with internalizing behavior are underdiagnosed; teachers are more likely to write referrals for students that are overtly disruptive, and screening tools to detect students with high levels of internalizing behavior are not sensitive and are rarely used in practice.<ref name="cecp.air.org"/>
Students with EBD with "[[Externalizing Disorders|externalizing]]" behavior may be aggressive, noncompliant, extroverted, or disruptive, and generally "act out" inappropriately. Students with EBD that show externalizing behavior are often diagnosed with [[attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]] (ADHD), [[oppositional defiant disorder]] (ODD), [[conduct disorder]], and/or [[bipolar disorder]]; however, this population can also include typically developing children that have [[operant conditioning|learned]] to exhibit externalizing behavior for various reasons (e.g., [[Reinforcement#Positive and negative|escape from academic demands]] or [[Reinforcement#Positive and negative|access to attention]]). These students often have difficulty inhibiting emotional responses resulting from anger, frustration, and disappointment, and may exhibit behaviors such as insulting, provoking, threatening, bullying, cursing, and fighting, along with other forms of aggression; noncompliance with and disrespect towards teachers and other authority figures is also common. Male students with EBD exhibit externalizing behavior more often than their female counterparts.<ref name="cecp.air.org"/>

{{Mental and behavioural disorders|selected = childhood}} {{Emotional and behavioral disorders}}

'''ExploreLearning''' is a [[Charlottesville, Virginia]]-based company which operates a large library of interactive [[Web-based simulation|online simulations]] for [[mathematics]] and [[science]] [[education]] in grades 3–12. These simulations are called '''Gizmos'''. The company's website describes their library of over 450<ref>[http://www.nasatalk.com/index.php?option=com_resource&controller=article&article=378&category_id=13&Itemid=93 ExploreLearning Gizmos], NASA Talk, a service of the Center for Educational Technologies at [[Wheeling Jesuit University]]</ref> Gizmos as the world's largest collection of such materials.
ExploreLearning also makes '''Reflex''', which is an online, game-based system that helps students of all ability levels to develop instant recall of basic math facts (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division).<ref>[http://www.siia.net/codies/2012/finalist_detail.asp?id=29 2012 CODiE Award Finalist listing for Best K-12 Instructional Solution]</ref>
ExploreLearning is a business unit of [[Cambium Learning Group]] ({{NASDAQ|ABCD}}).
==Gizmos==
''Gizmos'' are a collection of online interactive simulations that are operated by ExploreLearning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lhric.org/instructional_tech.cfm?subpage=775|title=Explorelearning Gizmos - Powerful Web Based Simulations for Math and Science, Grades 3-12|publisher=LHRIC|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref> The simulations are centered on science education and mathematics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tech4mathed.com/blog/2011/07/19/learning-with-gizmos/|title=Learning with Gizmos!|publisher=Tech 4 Mathed|date=July 19, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=1453186|title=Company Overview of ExploreLearning, Inc.|publisher=Business Week|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref>
These simulations have been recognized with many educational awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techlearning.com/article/15112|title=Awards of Excellence Winners 2008|publisher=Tech Learning|date=January 3, 2009|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref> The Gizmos earned finalist honors from the [[Software and Information Industry Association]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/explorelearning-gizmos-earn-finalist-honors-in-three-categories-from-software--information-industry-association-61720337.html|title=ExploreLearning Gizmos Earn Finalist Honors in Three Categories from Software & Information Industry Association|publisher=PRNewswire|accessdate=October 24, 2012}}</ref> They have been the subject of numerous scholarly studies of [[educational technology]].<ref>[http://publish.edu.uwo.ca/george.gadanidis/pdf/applets-Montreal.PDF http://publish.edu.uwo.ca/george.gadanidis/pdf/applets-Montreal.PDF], George Gadanidis, University of Western Ontario</ref><ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?cluster=11192436289240940927&hl=en&as_sdt=80000000000000 Analysis of Technology in the Classroom–Explorelearning's Gizmos], Kathryn Robles, Michigan State University, July 1, 2008</ref><ref>Sivit, F. (2004). [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?cluster=5794742535025461091&hl=en&as_sdt=80000000000000 A practical example of Mathematics Teaching using the Internet]. In L. Cantoni & C. McLoughlin (Eds.), Proceedings of World Conference on Educational Multimedia, Hypermedia and Telecommunications 2004 (pp. 3188–3193). Chesapeake, VA: AACE.</ref><ref>[http://www.infocus.com/ms/learningcenter/documents/ProjectingScienceandMathematics.pdf Projecting Science and Mathematics], Randy Bell & Joe Garofalo, School Science and Mathematics, Volume 105(1), January 2005</ref>
==Reflex==
''Reflex'' is an adaptive, game-based solution for assessing and developing math fact fluency in grade 2-8 students. Reflex has been recognized with many educational awards, including the "Best K-12 Instructional Solution" [[Software and Information Industry Association#CODiE Awards|Codie award]] from the Software and Information Industry Association.<ref>[https://www.siia.net/codies/2012/winners_detail.asp?nID=118 Winner In Best K-12 instructional Solution]</ref>
==References== <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.explorelearning.com/ ExploreLearning website] * [http://www.reflexmath.com/ Reflex website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100918215818/http://cambiumlearning.com/about/company.shtml Cambium Learning Group - About page] * [http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=1453186 ExploreLearning, Inc.] snapshot on Bloomberg Businessweek

{{Infobox government agency | agency_name = General Archive of the Nation | type = | nativename = Archivo General de la Nación | nativename_a = | nativename_r = | seal = | seal_width = | seal_caption = | logo = Logo_del_Archivo_General_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina.svg | logo_width = 150px | logo_caption = | picture = Leandro Alem Buenos Aires.jpg | picture_width = 250px | picture_caption = Main building. | formed = {{Start date and age|1821|08|21}} as "Archivo de la Provincia de Buenos Aires" | preceding1 = Archivo Gráfico de la Nación | preceding2 = | dissolved = | superseding1 = | superseding2 = | agency_type = [[Archive]] | jurisdiction = [[Argentina]] | headquarters = [[Leandro Alem Avenue|L.N. Alem Ave.]] n° 246,
[[Buenos Aires]] | coordinates = | motto = | employees = | budget = | minister1_name = | minister1_pfo = | minister2_name = | minister2_pfo = | deputyminister1_name = | deputyminister1_pfo = | deputyminister2_name = | deputyminister2_pfo = | chief1_name = Director | chief1_position = | chief2_name = Emilio Perina | chief2_position = | public_protector = | deputy = | parent_department = | parent_agency = [[Ministry of the Interior and Transport|Ministry of Interior]] | child1_agency = | child2_agency = | keydocument1 = | website = [http://www.agnargentina.gob.ar/ agnargentina.gob.ar] | map = | map_width = | map_caption = | footnotes = | embed = }} The '''General Archive of the Nation''' (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]: ''Archivo General de la Nación'') are the national archives of [[Argentina]]. It is a body under the Ministry of the Interior, Public Works and Housing, which aims to collect, order and keep the documentation that the law entrusts to it, to spread knowledge of the sources of Argentine history. ==Overview== The archives were established on August 28, 1821, by Governor [[Martín Rodríguez (politician)|Martín Rodríguez]] as the [[Buenos Aires Province]] Archive. The institution (AGN) absorbed numerous historical archives, libraries, and other collections over the subsequent decades, and in 1957 acquired the National Print Archive, a bureau established in 1939. Its collections occupy around 14 km (9 mi) of shelf stacks, and the AGN is a member of the [[Memory of the World Programme]], a [[UNESCO]] initiative. Operated by the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the AGN is organized into five departments: *''Written Documents''. This section curates parchments and manuscripts originating in the colonial [[Viceroyalty of Peru]] and [[Viceroyalty of Río de la Plata]], as well as those dating from the [[May Revolution]] of 1810, and of the series of fledgling governments assembled during the [[Argentine War of Independence]]. *''Photographic Documents''. [[Photograph]]s dating from 1853 to 1983, totalling over 800,000, as well as the Witcomb Collection (images taken in the renowned former [[art gallery]] of its many exhibitions). *''Library and Dissemination''. Oversees partnerships with archives and kindred institutions from around the world, serves as liaison to journalists and researchers, publishes all archive newsletters and periodicals, and maintains the sum of the institute's [[bibliography]] (over 100,000 books). This department, in turn, includes: **''Bibliography Fund''. 80,000 volumes, and a [[periodicals]] library of over 1,500 titles. **''Ernesto Celesia Collection''.13,000 volumes dating from the 19th century, and from several countries in South America. **''José Juan Biedma Collection''. 717 period publications regarding the [[Paraguayan War]] and [[Argentina-Chile relations|boundary disputes with Chile]]. **''José A. Pillado Collection''. 1,044 tomes on Argentine and Western Hemisphere history. **''[[Juan Domingo Perón]] Collection''. 4,000 volumes donated by the populist leader from his personal library. **''Periodicals Library''. Magazine and newspaper issues from the 19th and 20th centuries. *''Cinema and Media''. Over 3,000 [[Cinema of Argentina|films]], [[newsreel]]s, [[Ampex]] tapes, and more recent multimedia items. *''Intermediate Archive''. Established in 1979, the [[library science]] arm of the AGN assists archives and libraries nationwide and elsewhere with the classification and curation of items. This office also maintains the bulk of documentation produced by the array of [[State enterprise]]s, and was entrusted with these during President [[Carlos Menem]]'s [[privatization]]s drive. ===Headquarters=== Housed within the former Congress building in 1906, the AGN was relocated to its present address at 246 [[Leandro Alem Avenue]] (a former [[Banco Hipotecario|National Mortgage Bank]] office designed by Arturo Prins, and completed in 1920), upon the inaugural of the new Mortgage Bank building in 1950. The headquarters cannot house the entirety of its vast collections, which include over {{convert|17|km|mi}} of shelves of documentation;{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/ciudades/Historia-bien-custodiada_0_722327887.html|title=La Historia, bien custodiada|work=Clarín}} the Intermediate Archive, for instance, was opened in another, nearby building. Plans were announced for the archives' transfer to the former ALEA Building, a [[Rationalist architecture|Rationalist]] structure located behind the [[Alas Building]] that was ultimately sold to developer [[Inversiones y Representaciones Sociedad Anónima (IRSA)|IRSA]] in 1998.[http://www.clarin.com/diario/1998/08/31/e-04401d.htm ''Clarín'' (August 31, 1998)] {{es icon}} Construction was approved in 2012 for a new main building for the AGN, designed by Fabio Estremera, Luciana Deschamps and Javier Gavernet, and to be located on the site of the former [[Caseros Prison]] in the [[Parque Patricios]] district. ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|34|36|17|S|58|22|14|W|display=title}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Archivo General de la Nación Argentina}} https://www.youtube.com/user/AgnArgentina *[http://www.agnargentina.gob.ar/ Official website] [[Category:National archives|Argentina]] [[Category:Research institutes in Argentina]] [[Category:Argentine culture]] [[Category:Archives in Argentina]] [[Category:Libraries in Argentina]] [[Category:1821 establishments in Argentina]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1920]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Education in Buenos Aires]]

'''Hidrodoe''' is a [[science museum]] dedicated to [[water]] and located in the ''Netepark'' [[Herentals]], [[Belgium]]. The central part of Hidrodoe consists of ''Waterworld'' where the visitor can have experiences and perform experiments with regard to water. The ''Waterworld'' itself comprises the ''Drop'', the ''What Is Water Zone'', the ''History Cave'', the ''Landscape'' and the ''Aqua Station''.
==History== Hidrodoe was founded by Pidpa (''Provinciale en Intercommunale Drinkwatermaatschappij van de Provincie Antwerpen'') the water supply company of the [[Antwerp (province)|Antwerp]] province. Hidrodoe was declared open to the public on the [[World Day for Water]] 2003.
==Sources== * [http://www.nieuwsblad.be/Article/Detail.aspx?articleid=BA1V1IHC Record aantal bezoekers voor Hidrodoe] (Dutch) * [http://www.pidpa.be/nl/bedrijfsinfo/hidrodoe.htm Hidrodoe] (Pidpa) * [http://www.toerismevlaanderen.nl/tvl/view/nl/1747592-Bezienswaardigheden-Detail.html?view=2260997&speerpuntmaster=1748036&speerpunt=1757088&view=2354885 Hidrodoe] (Flanders)
==External links== * [http://www.hidrodoe.be/en/englishdefault.htm Hidrodoe]
[[Category:Science museums]] [[Category:Science and technology in Belgium]] [[Category:Flanders]] [[Category:Museums in Antwerp (province)]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox artist |name = Hilde Holger |image =Trcka Holger2 Kopie scharf.jpg | caption = Holger in 1925 |birth_name = Hilde Sofer |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1905|10|18}} |birth_place = [[Vienna]], [[Austria-Hungary]] |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2001|09|24|1905|10|18}} |death_place = [[Camden, London|Camden]], London |nationality = British, Austrian |field = Dance, choreography and [[teaching]] |movement = [[Expressionist dance|Expressionism]] and [[Physically integrated dance|Integrated dance]] |awards = |spouse = Adershir Kavershir Boman-Behram (1940–1975, 1989–2000) |website = {{URL|http://www.hildeholger.com|Official website}} }} [[File:Hilde Holger by Trcka c1926.jpg|thumb|Holger in 1926]] [[File:Trcka Holger.jpeg|thumb|Holger in 1926]] [[File:Trcka Holger 3.jpeg|thumb|Holger in 1926]] [[File:HH Dancer 1925-Anton Josef Trcka.jpeg|thumb|Holger in 1925]] '''Hilde Boman-Behram''' (née '''Hilde Sofer''', stage name '''Hilde Holger'''; 18 October 1905 – 24 September 2001) was an [[expressionist dance]]r, choreographer and [[dance teacher]] whose pioneering work in [[Physically integrated dance|integrated dance]] transformed [[modern dance]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://50yearsindance.com/category/hilde-holger/ |title=Hilde Holger : Central European Expressionist Dancer |publisher=www.50yearsindance.com/category/hilde-holger/ |date=2011 |access-date=12 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160212205154/http://50yearsindance.com/category/hilde-holger/ |archivedate=12 February 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="DN">{{cite web |url=http://www.hildeholger.com/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114194324/http://www.hildeholger.com/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 November 2006 |title=Hilde Holger: Central European Expressionist Dancer |publisher=hildeholger.com |date=2007 |access-date=18 December 2012 }}</ref>
==Family== Holger came from a [[Reform Judaism|liberal Jewish]] family. She was born in 1905, the daughter of Alfred and Elise Sofer Schreiber.<ref>Sassenberg, Marina (2009). [https://web.archive.org/web/20100408232906/http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/holger-hilde "Hilde Holger"]] in ''Jewish Women: A Comprehensive Historical Encyclopedia''. Jewish Women's Archive</ref> Her father wrote poetry, and had died by 1908. Her grandfather [[Shoemaking|made shoes]] for the [[Emperor of Austria|Austrian court]].
After [[Nazi Germany]] invaded [[Austria]], Holger fled [[Vienna]] in 1939, because her entry into England was denied, she went to [[India]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2000/mar/08/guardianobituaries2 |title=Adi Boman : Scientist on an unresolved search for a cancer cure |author=Pascal, Julia |work=The Guardian |date=8 March 2000 |access-date=18 December 2012 }}</ref> In [[Mumbai]] she met the [[Homeopathy|homeopath]] and art loving Dr. Ardershir Kavasji Boman-Behram, they married in 1940.<ref name="sueyounghistories.com">{{cite web | url=http://sueyounghistories.com/archives/2008/12/22/ardeshir-kavasji-boman-behram-1909-2000/ |title=Ardeshir Kavasji Boman Behram 1909–2000 |publisher=sueyounghistories.com |date=22 December 2008 |access-date=18 December 2012}}</ref> Her mother, step-father and fourteen other relatives all perished in [[the Holocaust]].
Hilde Holger had two children. The first was born 1946 in India, her daughter Primavera Boman-Behram. In New York she became a dancer, sculptor and [[jewelry designer]]. In 1948 Holger's family emigrated to Britain.<ref name="sueyounghistories.com" /> Her second child, a son named Darius Boman-Behram, was born in 1949. He had [[Down syndrome]], but inspired Holger to work with physically disabled people.
==Work== Hilde Holger started to dance at age six. At that time she was too young to join the ''Vienna State Academy of Music and Dramatic Art'', so she settled for ballroom dancing lessons taken with her sister (Hedi Sofer), until she was accepted to study with radical dancer [[Gertrud Bodenwieser]],<ref>Vernon-Warren, B. and Warren, C. (eds.) (1999) ''Gertrud Bodenwieser and Vienna's Contribution to Ausdruckstanz''. Routledge. p. 22. {{ISBN|90-5755-035-0}}.</ref> then a professor at the Vienna State Academy. They were admirers of the work of [[Isadora Duncan]] and [[Ruth St. Denis]], as well as the artists of the [[Vienna Secession|Secession]]. Holger soon rose to be Bodenwieser's principal dancer and friend, and toured with Bodenwieser's company all over [[Western Europe|Western]] and [[Eastern Europe]]. She toured with her own Hilde Holger Dance Group as well. At age eighteen she had her first solo performance in the Viennese Secession. Later in the Viennese Hagenbund and theaters in [[Vienna]], [[Paris]] and [[Berlin]], her much-lauded [[expressionist dance]] caused quite a stir. Because of her passion for dance, in 1926 she formed the New School for Movement Arts in Palais Ratibor, right in the heart of [[Vienna]]. Her children's performances were danced in parks and in front of monuments there.
On 12 March 1938 [[Adolf Hitler]]'s [[Nazi Germany]] sent troops into [[Austria]], and adopted a law to unify the country with [[Austria]], at that time it was forbidden for [[Jews]] to perform. She received help to flee [[Austria]] from her friend Charles Petrach. She decided to go to [[India]] because that country's art was the most compelling to Western people, she said at that time.
In [[India]] she had the opportunity to incorporate new experiences into her work, especially the hand movements of [[Indian dance]]. Classical Indian dance has over three hundred of them, used to express life and nature. In 1941 Holger founded a new school of dance in [[Bombay]], she took students of all race, religion and nationality without prejudice. Like when she was in [[Vienna]], Holger again took part in the artistic community. Amongst her friends whom collaborated with her were the Indian dancers [[Uday Shankar]] and [[Ram Gopal (dancer)|Ram Gopal]]<ref name="DN" />, the later of whom danced in Holger's dance school. In 1948 because of the [[partition of India]] and the growing violence between [[Muslims]] and [[Hindus]] she emigrated again, this time to Britain.
Once in England, her Holger Modern Ballet Group performed in parks, churches and theaters. She again opened a new dance school, ''The Hilde Holger School of Contemporary Dance'' and remained faithful to their style of teaching that the body and mind must form one unit in order to be a good dancer. Her breakthrough in London, 1951, celebrated Holger with the [[premiere]] of "Under the Sea", inspired by the composition by [[Camille Saint-Saens]].
In 1972 she performed a piece titled "Man against flood", it was in honour of the [[Chinese Communist Party]] member [[Rewi Alley]]. It included dancers forming a human wall against a flood of water.<ref>Lei, W. (28 October 1972) "Man Against Flood". ''[[The New Evening Post]]''(in Chinese).</ref>
Her performance "Apsaras" (1983) explored her experiences in [[India]]. In the summer of 1983 she went back to [[India]], where she had been last in the year 1948. There she worked as a choreographer for a large dance group directed by Sachin Shankar.
Holger was particularly proud of her work with the mentally handicapped. She created a form of [[dance therapy]] for children who, like her son Darius, have [[Down syndrome]]. Holger was the first choreographer who mixed professional dancers with young adults with severe learning disabilities. In 1968 at the [[Sadler's Wells]], Holger orchestrated "Towards the Light", with music by [[Edvard Grieg]]. It was pioneering, innovative, and one of the first integrated dance pieces to be seen on a professional stage.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2001/sep/26/guardianobituaries1 |title=Hilde Holger : As a dancer and teacher she kept the spirit of German expressionism alive in London |author=Pascal, Julia|work=The Guardian |date=26 September 2001 |access-date=27 December 2012}}</ref>
==Life work== Hilde Holger left a lasting impression on three generations of dancers and choreographers. While teaching her standards were high and she was not afraid of risk.<ref name="DN" /> She accepted students without prejudice, including students with disabilities, as long as they were sincere. One of her students, Wolfgang Stange, continued her work with people with learning difficulties, like [[Down syndrome]] and [[autism]], as well as people with physical disabilities. Stange's [[Amici Dance Theatre Company]] which was the first physically integrated dance company in Great Britain, which created a performance titled "Hilde" that was performed at the Riverside Theatre in London in 1996, and at the Odeon in [[Vienna]] in 1998. This HILDE Performance in Vienna excited the Ballet Master of the Vienna State Opera Ballet, who in turn put a performance on the stage of the Opera House with people with learning disabilities. These performances were received with great applause!
In her last few weeks Holger still held dance lessons in her basement studio in [[Camden Town|Camden]], London, where she lived for more than fifty years. Among some of her students included [[Lindsay Kemp]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2018/aug/26/lindsay-kemp-obituary |title=Lindsay Kemp obituary |publisher=The Guardian |date=2018 |access-date=9 September 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2018/aug/25/british-choreographer-and-mime-lindsay-kemp-dies|title=British choreographer and mime Lindsay Kemp dies |publisher=The Guardian |date=2018 |access-date=9 September 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usapostclick.com/lindsay-kemp-choreographer-and-bowie-mentor-dies-at-80/ |title=Lindsay Kemp, choreographer and Bowie mentor, dies at 80 |publisher=UsaPostClick |date=2018 |access-date=9 September 2018 }}</ref>, Liz Aggiss, [[Jane Asher]], [[Royston Maldoom]] and Carl Campbell.
