revision.text:
{{Infobox soap character |series = Neighbours |image= Jade Mitchell.jpg |imagesize= 200px |name= Jade Mitchell |portrayer= [[Gemma Pranita]] |introducer= [[Susan Bower]] |years= 2010–12 |classification= [[List of past Neighbours characters#M|Former; regular]] |first= 10 December 2010 |last = 29 October 2012 |born= 24 April 1986<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scmedia.com.au/content/eguide.aspx?ch=BALELEVEN:ELEVEN%20-%20Ballarat&dd=2012-04-24|title=Tuesday, 24-Apr-2012|publisher=[[Southern Cross Media]]|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> <!--Birth year shown on 19 April 2011 (episode 6142)--> |home = [[Los Angeles]] |occupation= Personal trainer |mother = Fiona Mitchell |father = John Mitchell |halfsisters = [[Sonya Mitchell]] |first cousins = [[Sonya Mitchell]] |nephews = [[Callum Jones]] }} '''Jade Mitchell''' is a fictional character from the Australian soap opera ''[[Neighbours]]'', played by [[Gemma Pranita]]. Pranita's casting was announced on 7 September 2010 and she began filming her first scenes the day before. The actress was in Russia when she received a call from her agent about the audition for ''Neighbours''. She returned to Australia and her agent managed to get her in on the last day. Pranita won the part of Jade and she was given a twelve-month contact with the show. She relocated to Melbourne for filming and she made her first screen appearance as Jade during the episode broadcast on 10 December 2010. In June 2012, Pranita announced her departure from ''Neighbours''. She filmed her final scenes in August and departed on 29 October 2012.
Jade is the younger sister of [[Sonya Mitchell]] ([[Eve Morey]]). Prior to her arrival in Erinsborough, Jade had not seen Sonya for seven years. Pranita revealed that Jade was holding onto one of Sonya's darkest secrets and that she would have the potential to cause trouble for her. Jade has been described as "vivacious, confident and beautiful" by a writer for the official ''Neighbours'' website. She is an opinionated feminist, who has a fighting spirit. While Jade is flirtatious and a bit of a maneater, Pranita said she is "anti-relationships" and more interested in finding fun. Jade is a personal trainer and Pranita chose to take up an exercise routine for the role.
Jade's early storylines often saw her trying to mend the rocky relationship she had with her sister and bond with her nephew, [[Callum Jones]] ([[Morgan Baker]]), who she "loves and adores". Other storylines have revolved Jade's relationships with men. She immediately clashed with Sonya's partner and kissed [[Lucas Fitzgerald]] ([[Scott Major]]) shortly after her arrival. She had a [[one-night stand]] with [[Mark Brennan (Neighbours)|Mark Brennan]] ([[Scott McGregor (model)|Scott McGregor]]) and developed feelings for her housemate, [[Kyle Canning]] ([[Chris Milligan]]). The couple initially entered into a [[Casual relationship|friends with benefits]] arrangement and Jade began an affair with [[Malcolm Kennedy]] ([[Benjamin McNair]]). Kyle and Jade later started a serious relationship together.
==Casting== On 7 September 2010, a reporter for the ''[[Herald Sun]]'' announced Pranita had joined the cast of ''Neighbours'' as Jade Mitchell.<ref name="Neighbourhood">{{Cite news|title=Pranita moves into Neighbourhood|date=7 September 2010|work=[[Herald Sun]]|page=21}}</ref> They said Pranita's character would arrive on Ramsay Street to expose a secret held by her sister, [[Sonya Mitchell|Sonya]] ([[Eve Morey]]).<ref name="Neighbourhood"/> Pranita was in Russia researching [[Anton Chekhov]] when her agent called her about an audition for ''Neighbours''.<ref name="DoorOpen">{{Cite web|url=http://neighbours.com.au/One_Door_Closes_Another_Opens!.htm|title=One Door Closes and Another Opens!|date=12 October 2010|publisher=[[Network Ten]]|accessdate=12 October 2010}}</ref> She told a writer for [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] "They were holding auditions and I happened to be in Russia doing a Chekhov pilgrimage because I'd received a grant. I just thought, oh well, it's not to be but then I came back and my agent called and said I can squeeze you in on the last day. So within a week I was moving cities."<ref name="Pilgrimage">{{Cite web|url=http://www.channel5.com/shows/neighbours/news/gemmas-ramsay-st-pilgrimage|title=Gemma's Ramsay St pilgrimage|date=8 February 2011|work=[[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]|accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> Pranita was initially given a twelve-month contact and she began filming her first scenes on 6 September.<ref name="Neighbourhood"/><ref name="Prisoner">{{Cite web|url=http://neighbours.com.au/Prisoner-Babes-Hit-the-Street.htm|title=Prisoner Babes Hit the Street!|date=7 September 2010|publisher=[[Network Ten]]|accessdate=8 September 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100916212115/http://neighbours.com.au/Prisoner-Babes-Hit-the-Street.htm|archivedate=16 September 2010}}</ref> She made her first on screen appearance as Jade in December 2010.<ref name="Prisoner"/> During an interview published the ''Neighbours'' official website, Pranita revealed that she had found the filming schedule was "quite full-on" and that she was still getting used to the early starts.<ref name="PUncovered">{{cite web|url=http://neighbours.com.au/Gemma-Uncovered.htm|title=Gemma Uncovered|date=5 May 2011|publisher=[[Network Ten]]|accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref>
==Development==
===Characterisation=== Jade has been described as being "vivacious, confident and beautiful" by a writer for the official ''Neighbours'' website.<ref name="JMAus">{{cite web|url=http://neighbours.com.au/6972.htm|title=Jade Mitchell|publisher=[[Network Ten]]|accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> She has a flirtatious side and a "fighting spirit", which means nothing will stand in her way.<ref name="JMAus"/><ref name="JMHoly">{{cite web|url=http://holysoap.channel5.com/neighbours/cast/jade-mitchell-12496|title=Jade Mitchell|work=[[Holy Soap]]|accessdate=6 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xMAur1XJ?url=http://holysoap.channel5.com/neighbours/cast/jade-mitchell-12496|archivedate=21 March 2011|df=}}</ref> Jackie Brygel, writing for ''[[TV Week]]'', said Jade "clearly isn't backward in coming forward when it comes to getting what she wants in life."<ref name="LookLucas">{{cite journal|last=Brygel|first=Jackie|date=11–17 December 2010|title=Look out, Lucas!|journal=[[TV Week]]|page=18}}</ref> Pranita told Brygel that Jade is a feminist and a bit of a man eater.<ref name="LookLucas"/> The actress believed that she was not that similar to her character, saying "She is very opinionated which I can be, but I don't think I'm brash with my ideas or assert my ideas on to people which she does."<ref name="Pilgrimage"/> Pranita also said Jade is "anti-relationships" and more interested in having fun, whereas she has been in a relationship for five years.<ref name="Pilgrimage"/> However, when she was asked about what she would like to see in Jade's future, Pranita said she wanted her to meet a love interest who "really challenges her and breaks her down a bit, because she's a little bit of a martyr."<ref name="SisterAct">{{cite web|url=http://holysoap.channel5.com/neighbours/news/sister-act-sonya-and-jade-12279|title=Sister act: Sonya and Jade|date=14 February 2011|work=[[Holy Soap]]|accessdate=10 May 2011}}</ref>
Jade is a personal trainer and a "fitness freak".<ref name="Pilgrimage"/> Pranita took up exercise during her research for the role, something she had not done before, and commented that she had enjoyed it.<ref name="Pilgrimage"/> In May 2011, Pranita confessed that she had not been able to maintain Jade's fitness routine and that, while she was still into it, her filming schedule had increased.<ref name="PUncovered"/> The actress also revealed that she had found that she now shared some similar personality traits with her character.<ref name="PUncovered"/> Pranita admitted that she and Jade hide their vulnerability and they do not like putting their "issues onto other people".<ref name="PUncovered"/> In July 2011, executive producer, Susan Bower revealed Jade would continue to be a "naughty girl" and that she was hiding a dark secret.<ref name="Teases2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/news/a330665/neighbours-character-teasers-from-exec-susan-bower.html|title=Exclusive: 'Neighbours' character teasers from exec Susan Bower|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=20 July 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=20 July 2011}}</ref> Pranita teased the storyline further saying Jade was too proud to share her secret with anyone and initially only the audience would know what the secret was.<ref name="SurpriseViewers">{{cite web|url=http://www.channel5.com/shows/neighbours/interviews/gemma-jade-will-surprise-viewers|title=Gemma: Jade will surprise viewers|date=27 July 2011|work=[[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]|accessdate=27 July 2011}}</ref> Viewers would also see Jade go on a "self-destructive path and becomes involved with an older man."<ref name="SurpriseViewers"/>
During an August 2011 interview with [[Digital Spy]]'s Daniel Kilkelly, Pranita said she was pleased with how the audience had responded to her character considering she was a "big personality".<ref name="GP">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/interviews/a334889/gemma-pranita-neighbours-jade-mitchell.html|title=Gemma Pranita - 'Neighbours' Jade Mitchell|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=13 August 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref> Pranita quipped that viewers had forgiven her "brash approach" and said they liked having a strong female character around.<ref name="GP"/> Asked if she had managed to put her own stamp on the character, Pranita revealed "I think there has been a marriage between the work I've done and what the writers have created, so we have inspired each other. Jade has developed into exactly what I would like her to be."<ref name="GP"/> Pranita said she was pleased that Jade was getting her own storylines away from her sister, as it gives her the opportunity to discover new things about her character.<ref name="GP"/> She added that Jade was starting to become tri-dimensional and the audience were learning that she is quite complex.<ref name="GP"/> Pranita later called her character "beautifully flawed".<ref name="FByrne">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/neighbours-star-gemma-pranita-seeks-new-roles/story-e6frf96o-1226389547296|title=Neighbours star Gemma Pranita seeks new roles|last=Byrne|first=Fiona|date=8 June 2012|work=[[Herald Sun]]|accessdate=8 June 2012}}</ref>
===Family=== {{Quote box|width=20%|align=right|bgcolor=#cccfff|quote="I don’t have a sister which I think is why I've had this tornado love affair with Eve. She is like the sister I've never had."<ref name="PUncovered"/>|source=—Pranita on having an on-screen sister}} Before her arrival in Erinsborough, Jade had been estranged from her sister for seven years.<ref name="JMHoly"/> Jade calls Sonya out of the blue and Pranita explained "Sonya's response is 'Why are you calling me? Why now? Don't come anywhere near me!' But Jade keeps ringing and harassing Sonya and then rocks up on her doorstep."<ref name="SecretPast">{{Cite journal|last=Brygel|first=Jackie|date=6–10 December 2010|title=Sonya's secret past|journal=[[TV Week]]|page=29}}</ref> Jade's appearance on her doorstep sends Sonya into a panic.<ref name="DoorOpen"/> Pranita told ''TV Week's'' Jackie Brygel that the history between Jade and Sonya is bad and that Jade is "holding one of Sonya's darkest secrets".<ref name="SecretPast"/> Pranita believed that Jade had the potential to cause a lot of trouble for Sonya and expose her for lying to the people around her. She added that Jade would "completely rock the boat."<ref name="SecretPast"/> Morey revealed that the last time Sonya saw her younger sister was when she left her son, [[Callum Jones|Callum]] ([[Morgan Baker]]) with their grandmother, [[Hilda Jones|Hilda]] (Maureen Edwards). Sonya believes that Jade has come to Erinsborough to get "some revenge."<ref name="SisterAct"/> When Jade learns that Sonya has been living with Callum and that he is unaware of who she really is, she urges her sister to tell him the truth.<ref name="SisterAct"/> However, after seeing how happy the family is, Jade changes her mind.<ref name="JMHoly"/>
Pranita stated that Jade and Sonya's relationship was initially very "rocky", but after Jade sees how happy her sister is, she becomes "fiercely supportive" of her.<ref name="SisterAct"/> Pranita said "It's almost the Mitchell sisters against Ramsay Street."<ref name="SisterAct"/> Of her role in the Sonya/Callum storyline, Pranita told a writer for the show's official website "I was overwhelmed and completely intimidated, especially since Jade is such a confident character. I was so nervous and terrified but I had to exude confidence which was really hard. But at the same time it was thrilling. I was definitely thrown in the deep end with a bang."<ref name="PUncovered"/> Susan Bower said Jade "loves and adores" her sister and nephew and she quipped that the audience could tell Jade is "not a cold fish."<ref name="Teases2011"/> Jade does not initially get on well with Sonya's partner, [[Toadfish Rebecchi]] ([[Ryan Moloney]]). Pranita said both characters struggle with each other.<ref name="SharedLove">{{cite web|url=http://www.channel5.com/shows/neighbours/news/jade-and-toadies-shared-love|title=Jade and Toadie's shared love|date=13 February 2011|work=[[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]|accessdate=22 November 2011}}</ref> She told a reporter for Channel 5 "It's a very push-pull relationship and they can both be quite fiery so they really lay into each other."<ref name="SharedLove"/> Jade and Toadie eventually learn they both have a secret passion for board games and they begin to bond with one another.<ref name="SharedLove"/> When Sonya suffers a pregnancy scare she immediately confides in Jade, who is "level-headed" about the situation. She encourages her sister to take a second pregnancy test just to be sure.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Herbison|first=Jason|date=3–9 September 2011|title=Sonya's story is making me broody!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=35|page=43}}</ref> Pranita later stated that Jade and Sonya would continue to support each other as sisters.<ref name="GP"/>
===Relationship with Kyle Canning=== When Pranita was asked which character she would like Jade to start a relationship with, she chose [[Kyle Canning]] ([[Chris Milligan]]).<ref name="PUncovered"/> She thought Jade and Kyle's contrasting personalities would work together, saying "They're opposites and personally, I really enjoy working with Chris. I think the characters can learn a lot from each other. Jade is very worldly and smart and Kyle has a more simple and uncomplicated nature."<ref name="PUncovered"/> Jade eventually develops feelings for Kyle and Pranita believed her character's feelings were for real and said it had taken her by surprise.<ref name="SurpriseViewers"/> Jade and Kyle share a house together and on the night of their housewarming party they kiss, making Jade fall for Kyle even more.<ref name="SurpriseViewers"/> However, she is frustrated when Kyle reveals that he still sees her as a friend.<ref name="SurpriseViewers"/><ref>{{cite journal|date=9–15 July 2011|title=What happens when?|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=27|page=31}}</ref> Pranita told a Channel 5 reporter that Jade is trying to fight her feelings for Kyle because she is terrified of relationships, however she does want him.<ref name="SurpriseViewers"/> Jade decides to "let go of her reservations" and gets dressed up to make a move on Kyle.<ref name="Woo">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/scoop/a335162/neighbours-jade-finally-tries-to-woo-kyle-video.html|title='Neighbours' Jade finally tries to woo Kyle - video|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=15 August 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=2 October 2011}}</ref> They have sex and Kyle suggests they engage in a [[Casual relationship|friends with benefits]] arrangement to which Jade agrees.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/soaps/neighbours/story-so-far/has-susan-gone-too-far/10436|title=Has Susan gone too far?|date=13 September 2011|work=[[What's on TV]]|accessdate=24 September 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120918145200/http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/soaps/neighbours/story-so-far/has-susan-gone-too-far/10436|archivedate=18 September 2012|df=}}</ref> Pranita told an ''Inside Soap'' journalist that Jade agrees to the arrangement as it is her way of working Kyle out of her system, but the opposite happens and she falls in love with him.<ref name="Jealous">{{cite journal|date=1–7 October 2011|title=Jealous Jade!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=39|page=28}}</ref> Kyle is unaware of Jade's feelings for him and he flirts with local nurse, [[Danielle Paquette]] (Georgia Bolton), in front of her.<ref name="Jealous"/> Jade becomes jealous and Pranita said she has never been affected like that before and is unsure how to handle it.<ref name="Jealous"/> {{Quote box|width=20%|align=left|bgcolor=#cccfff|quote="I would like to see her settle down, although I don't think she would actually settle. But it would be a really interesting chapter in her life to be in a solid relationship for the first time."<ref name="SurpriseViewers"/>|source=—Pranita on seeing her character settle down}} Jade's situation gets worse as her new housemate, [[Rhys Lawson|Rhys]] ([[Ben Barber]]), notices how uncomfortable she is around Kyle and Danielle.<ref name="Jealous"/> Rhys confronts Jade and she denies her interest in Kyle because she is scared Rhys will tell him. Of this, Pranita said "Deep down, she's afraid that if Kyle ever finds out the truth about her feelings, he'll simply reject her..."<ref name="Jealous"/> Pranita quipped that Jade is too proud to admit she has fallen for someone, but Rhys becomes determined to make Jade face up to reality. Pranita explained "It's really challenging having that dynamic in the house, with another person knowing her secret. She knows he'll use it to blackmail her eventually."<ref name="CheatingHeart">{{cite journal|date=22–28 October 2011|title=Cheating heart|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=43|page=24}}</ref> Kyle leaves Erinsborough for a few weeks to care for his sick mother. He returns in time for Christmas, where he gives Jade a handmade photo frame at a housemates lunch.<ref name="EverAfter">{{cite journal|title=Happily ever after?|date=26 November – 2 December 2011|work=[[TV Week]]|first=Lucy|last=Walker|pages=27|issue=48}}</ref> Pranita told Lucy Walker of ''TV Week'' that Jade is touched by the gift as Kyle used his money to make her "something meaningful."<ref name="EverAfter"/> She is also surprised that he went to that much effort for her and the gesture makes Jade fall for Kyle even more.<ref name="EverAfter"/> The couple share a passionate kiss under some mistletoe and Jade takes the opportunity to open up to Kyle about her commitment issues. She reveals that she was physically abused by her ex-boyfriend.<ref name="EverAfter"/> Pranita explained "She's never told anyone, not even her sister, Sonya. But Jade's a vault like that and, as hard as it is for her to talk about it, deep down there's an element of relief to share a part of her life with him. It is so difficult for her to talk about her personal life to anyone. So that's a really big deal."<ref name="EverAfter"/>
The moment between Jade and Kyle is ruined when Kyle learns of her relationship with [[Malcolm Kennedy]] ([[Benjamin McNair]]).<ref name="EverAfter"/> Jade tells Kyle that she only went with Malcolm to get over him, but it was unsuccessful.<ref name="JKTwist">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/news/a354461/neighbours-airs-new-jade-kyle-twist.html|title='Neighbours' airs new Jade, Kyle twist|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=5 December 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=7 December 2011}}</ref> Jade then declares her love for Kyle, but he turns his back on her and Jade decides to leave Erinsborough and go to Sydney.<ref name="JKTwist"/> However, she changes her mind at the last minute and decides not to get on the coach because she cannot leave Kyle.<ref name="JKClimax">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/news/a354672/neighbours-airs-kyle-jade-plot-climax.html|title='Neighbours' airs Kyle, Jade plot climax|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=6 December 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=7 December 2011}}</ref> Jade then finds Kyle has come to stop her and they kiss.<ref name="JKClimax"/> The conclusion to Jade and Kyle's "will they, won't they?" storyline aired during ''Neighbours''' 2011 season finale week.<ref name="JKClimax"/> When asked about Jade and Kyle finally becoming a couple, Pranita told ''Inside Soap's'' Jason Herbison "Kyle is definitely thinking, 'Thank God she's finally come round!'. But I'm sure he's walking on eggshells because Jade is still so guarded."<ref name="LoveList">{{cite journal|last=Herbison|first=Jason|date=11–17 February 2012|title=Love list 2012 - Kyle and Jade|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=6|pages=48–49}}</ref> Pranita explained that Jade has a lot of rules when it comes to relationships and she is on a huge emotional journey. The actress said that Jade wants to enjoy it, but cannot help worrying about when it will all stop.<ref name="LoveList"/>
Jade's relationship with Kyle ends in July 2012, after Kate confesses that they kissed.<ref name="BrygelMiller">{{cite journal|last=Brygel|first=Jackie|author2=Miller, Erin|date=7–13 July 2012|title=Kate confesses|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=27|pages=44–45}}</ref> Kate is feeling guilty about her kiss with Kyle and she tells Jade in the middle of the street. Jade then makes it clear that she want nothing more to do with Kate.<ref name="BrygelMiller"/> Pranita told ''TV Week's'' Jackie Brygel and Erin Miller that the news comes a complete shock to Jade and she is not sure how to process it in the moment. Pranita revealed "She had no clue, not a hint, that something was happening between them. Jade allowed herself to fall completely for Kyle. She felt as though she was in this amazing place and now Kate bursts that bubble in the most shocking of ways."<ref name="BrygelMiller"/> The actress explained that Jade feels it is the worst sort of betrayal and after she confronts Kyle, she "goes into self-defence protection mode" and decides to eliminate him from her life.<ref name="BrygelMiller"/> Pranita stated that she understands her character's reaction as she needs time to process and reflect. However, it is hard for her to punish Kyle as she really loved him.<ref name="BrygelMiller"/>
===Other relationships===
====Lucas Fitzgerald==== Shortly after her arrival, Jade sets her sights on [[Lucas Fitzgerald]] ([[Scott Major]]). After spending the evening flirting with him, she kisses him.<ref name="LookLucas"/> Pranita said Jade thinks Lucas is cute and there is an attraction between them. Of the kiss, Pranita said "Jade and Lucas have only just met, but Jade is very free-spirited and does things on impulse."<ref name="LookLucas"/> Lucas pulls away from the kiss as he has feelings for someone else, but Sonya witnesses it and is angry with her sister.<ref name="LookLucas"/> Pranita admitted that she was nervous about filming the scene as it was her first screen kiss and it occurred during her first week on the show.<ref name="LookLucas"/> When asked if the kiss is the start of a romance for Jade and Lucas, Pranita said that Jade is caught up with a lot of family issues for the moment, but anything could happen in the future.<ref name="LookLucas"/> In February 2011, Pranita commented on Jade and Lucas, saying they are both strong characters, who are quite similar as they are "loners who dance to their own beat."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/news/a304779/gemma-pranita-teases-neighbours-love.html|title=Gemma Pranita teases 'Neighbours' love|last=Rainey|first=Naomi|date=19 February 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> Major also said that he would like his character to have a romance with Jade. Lucas and Jade become friends after the kiss and they often argue, which led to Major calling their relationship a "love/hate stand-off."<ref name="ScottLJRomance">{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/soaps/neighbours/news/neighbours-scott-id-love-lucas-and-jade-romance/12086|title=Neighbours' Scott: I'd love Lucas and Jade romance|date=9 March 2011|work=[[What's on TV]]|accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> Major revealed that he had asked the writers to put Lucas and Jade together, but they did not seem keen.<ref name="ScottLJRomance"/> [[File:Scott McGregor 2.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Jade had a one-night stand with Mark Brennan, played by Scott McGregor (''pictured'').]]
====Mark Brennan==== In April 2011, a reporter for ''TV Week'' stated that Jade would have a [[one-night stand]] with [[Mark Brennan (Neighbours)|Mark Brennan]] ([[Scott McGregor (model)|Scott McGregor]]).<ref name="TwistForJade">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/news/a316669/neighbours-twist-ahead-for-mark-jade.html|title='Neighbours' twist ahead for Mark, Jade|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=27 April 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=27 April 2011}}</ref> Jade and Mark grow closer after he goes for a drink at Charlie's, they play pool together and then "find themselves kissing."<ref name="TwistForJade"/> Pranita told the reporter that Jade is "risking the wrath" of her close friend [[Kate Ramsay]] ([[Ashleigh Brewer]]), who recently broke up with Mark.<ref name="TwistForJade"/> She said "Jade doesn't consider Kate in that moment, as she knows she's broken up with Brennan and doesn't appreciate that it's just not cool to hook up with other people's exes. But I think Kate will be horrified and shocked and angry."<ref name="TwistForJade"/> McGregor told Digital Spy's Daniel Kilkelly that he did not think Jade and Mark would have made a good match, and that it was a one off thing. He added that in some ways they regret it, but in others they do not.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/scoop/a330497/neighbours-scott-mcgregor-on-bowing-out-as-brennan.html|title='Neighbours': Scott McGregor on bowing out as Brennan|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=18 July 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=18 July 2011}}</ref> Pranita later revealed that what Jade had learnt from the one-night stand with Mark was not to risk a friendship for a man again.<ref name="SurpriseViewers"/>
====Malcolm Kennedy==== Jade befriends Malcolm Kennedy in October 2011, and they begin flirting with each other.<ref name="Mal">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/posts/view/215904|title=Jade Mitchell turns her attentions to Malcolm Kennedy|last=Hill|first=Susan|date=16 October 2011|work=[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]|accessdate=21 November 2011}}</ref> Susan Hill from the ''Daily Star'' said Jade uses Malcolm to distract her from her feelings for Kyle. The fact Malcolm is married appeals to her because she knows there is no chance of a relationship there.<ref name="CheatingHeart"/><ref name="Mal"/> Jade tells her sister that she is no longer thinking about Kyle and a concerned Sonya tries to warn her off Malcolm. However, Jade decides she needs some fun and reckons he is the person to help her.<ref name="Mal"/> Jade and Malcolm's innocent flirting turns into something more serious when they arrange a "late-night rendezvous."<ref name="CheatingHeart"/> Malcolm reminds Jade he is married, but that does not stop them from kissing.<ref name="CheatingHeart"/> Pranita said her character is a commitment-phobe and she told a ''TV Week'' writer "The reason she goes to Malcolm is purely to gain some sort of control back in her life because everything's spiralling out of control due to these feelings she has for Kyle. Her default position is to go back to what she knows - which is to hook up with men who won't want anything serious, like taken men or people who are up for a one-night stand. He's like a safety harness really."<ref name="CheatingHeart"/> Malcolm and Jade's affair comes to an end when [[Karl Kennedy]] ([[Alan Fletcher (actor)|Alan Fletcher]]) finds out about it.<ref name="SaucyAffair">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/soaperstar/view/222752/Neighbours-Malcolm-Kennedy-ends-saucy-affair/|title=Malcolm Kennedy Ends Saucy Affair|last=Hill|first=Susan|date=27 November 2011|work=[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]|accessdate=30 November 2011}}</ref> Jade does not appear to be fussed about the end of the affair and Malcolm is left "a little rattled" by her reaction.<ref name="SaucyAffair"/>
====Troy Miller==== [[File:Dieter Brummer 2011 (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|150px|In 2012, it emerged that Jade had been in an abusive relationship with [[Troy Miller (Neighbours)|Troy Miller]] ([[Dieter Brummer]] (''pictured'')).]] In late 2011, Jade opened up to Kyle about her past and revealed that she had been in a relationship with an abusive man.<ref name="TroysBack">{{cite journal|last=Mercado|first=Andrew|date=26 May – 1 June 2012|title=Troy's back!|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=21|page=40}}</ref><ref name="GShearer">{{cite news|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/ipad/tv-learning-the-ropes-on-soaps/story-fn6ck8la-1226214300077|title=TV: Learning the ropes on soaps|last=Shearer|first=Geoff|date=6 December 2011|work=[[The Courier-Mail]]|accessdate=29 June 2012}}</ref> Pranita revealed to Geoff Shearer of ''[[The Courier-Mail]]'' that Jade's ex would be introduced to the show in the new year.<ref name="GShearer"/> When [[Troy Miller (Neighbours)|Troy Miller]] ([[Dieter Brummer]]) returned to Ramsay Street in May 2012, Jade appeared "horrified" at his reappearance and in "an explosive development" it was revealed that he was her abusive ex-boyfriend.<ref name="TroysBack"/> Claire Crick from ''[[All About Soap]]'' commented that Troy "stooped to a new low" when he seemed almost proud of the fact that he was once "heavy-handed" with Jade.<ref name="TrueColours">{{cite web|url=http://www.allaboutsoap.co.uk/blog/neighbours-troy-shows-his-true-colours/|title=Neighbours: Troy shows his true colours!|last=Crick|first=Claire|date=27 June 2012|work=[[All About Soap]]|accessdate=30 October 2012}}</ref> Crick went on to say "We're so used to seeing Jade as the feisty fitness freak who's always in control, but Troy clearly has a hold over her that no one else has. She's still terrified of her ex, and it seems she's got good reason to be. We always knew he was a bad egg, but who'd have thought he was nasty enough to hurt his girlfriend?"<ref name="TrueColours"/> Pranita explained that she had to some research into domestic, physical and emotional violence for the storyline, as she had never been in an abusive relationship.<ref name="GoodbyeVideo">{{cite video|people=Pranita, Jade|year=2012|title=Gemma Pranita on leaving Neighbours|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-R503ciY-CM&sns=tw|medium=Video interview|publisher=[[Neighbours]] and [[Eleven (TV channel)|Eleven]]|accessdate=29 October 2012}}</ref>
Troy was Sonya's ex-boyfriend and the biological father of Callum. He returned to try and win custody of his son. After Callum confronts his father about reneging on a deal they had, Troy snaps and refuses to let him leave his house.<ref name="Siege">{{cite journal|date=16–22 June 2012|title=Siege situation|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=24|pages=34–35}}</ref> Both Sonya and Jade become anxious at the development and eventually burst through the door and get Callum out, but Troy then locks them inside.<ref name="Siege"/> Pranita revealed "Jade is taking on the very protective auntie role of looking after Callum. But she also knows Callum has no idea about how much of an untamed wild animal Troy is. Now, locked in the house with, she feels this is history repeating itself. Jade loathes Troy more now than she ever has."<ref name="Siege"/> The actress found the scenes were some of the toughest she has ever shot, as they were unlike the normal drama they usually filmed. She called the storyline "intense" and found it harder than normal to let go of it when she went home.<ref name="Siege"/> Pranita later stated that the Troy storyline had been her most difficult storyline to film during her time on ''Neighbours''.<ref name="GoodbyeVideo"/>
===Departure=== On 8 June 2012, Fiona Byrne of the ''Herald Sun'' reported Pranita would be departing ''Neighbours''.<ref name="FByrne"/> Byrne revealed that the actress had been offered a contract extension, but she had decided to leave.<ref name="FByrne"/> Pranita stated "The decision was made with a heavy heart as I love this job, but I just felt that two years was long enough to play one character. I became an actor to play lots of different characters and, while Jade has been an amazing role, I feel I want to challenge myself to do other things."<ref name="Exit">{{cite web|url=http://www.channel5.com/shows/neighbours/news/jade-star-gemma-to-exit-ramsay-street|title=Jade star Gemma to exit Ramsay Street|date=8 June 2012|work=[[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]|accessdate=8 June 2012}}</ref> She explained that she had enjoyed working on ''Neighbours'' that she would miss her co-stars, in particular Milligan and Morey.<ref name="Exit"/> The actress took a break at the end of June to spend time with her boyfriend, before filming Jade's departure storyline.<ref name="FByrne"/> Pranita filmed her final scenes on 9 August.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/news/a398396/neighbours-gemma-pranita-bids-farewell-on-last-day-as-jade-pic.html|title='Neighbours' Gemma Pranita bids farewell on last day as Jade - pic|last=Millar|first=Paul|date=9 August 2012|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=9 August 2012}}</ref> Pranita teased that "hearts will be broken and lots tears will be shed" when Jade leaves, while executive producer [[Richard Jasek]] revealed Jade would be presented with an amazing opportunity.<ref name="Exit"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/interviews/a390834/neighbours-producer-richard-jasek-talks-show-future-interview.html|title='Neighbours' producer Richard Jasek talks show future - interview|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=1 July 2012|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref>
Jade is given the chance to work in the United States and she and Kyle begin a long-distance relationship.<ref name="Splitting">{{cite journal|last=Brygel|first=Jackie|date=20–26 October 2012|title=Splitting the difference|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=41|page=41}}</ref> On her return, Jade asks Kyle to accompany her. However, after Kyle learns that she is going back to the US for a year, he states that his life is in Erinsborough. He then breaks up with Jade.<ref name="Splitting"/> When asked if her heart went out to Kyle, Pranita said "Of course. I'm someone who has been in a long-distance relationship myself. I think it's always harder being the person who's left behind, since the other person is on a new crusade and adventure. Kyle and Jade have this awful, mutual break-up where they're both crying."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s14/neighbours/news/a432459/neighbours-gemma-pranita-exit-tears-were-real.html|title='Neighbours' Gemma Pranita: 'Exit tears were real'|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=22 October 2012|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref> Jade departed on 29 October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scmedia.com.au/content/eguide.aspx?ch=SUNELEVEN:ELEVEN%20-%20Sunshine%20Coast&dd=2012-10-29|title=Monday, 29-Oct-2012|publisher=[[Southern Cross Media]]|accessdate=15 October 2012}}</ref>
==Storylines== Jade comes to [[Erinsborough]] to visit her estranged sister Sonya and mend their relationship. Jade drags Sonya out for a drink and ends up kissing Sonya's friend Lucas Fitzgerald. When Jade tells Sonya she has no where else to go, Sonya allows her to stay with her. Jade starts teaching yoga at the local gym, and befriends Kate Ramsay. When she gets in trouble for flashing at Charlie's bar, Sonya tells her to leave. [[Zeke Kinski]] ([[Matthew Werkmeister]]) invites Jade to stay next door at the Kennedy house. When Sonya partner, Toadfish Rebecchi, returns home, Sonya is forced to introduce Jade to him and his son, Callum. Jade then realises that Callum is Sonya's son and threatens to tell him the truth. But once she sees how happy Callum is, she decides to keep Sonya's secret and moves in with her sister. Jade clashes with Toadie clash several times, but their relationship improves when they discover they have a mutual love of board games. When Callum's great-grandmother dies, it prompts him to try to find his mother. Callum eventually learns Sonya is his mother, and Jade comforts her sister when Toadie throws them out.
Jade asks Kyle Canning to help her attract female gym clients, but has to fire him when he is late for a meeting with a client. Jade has a one-night stand with Kate's ex-boyfriend, Mark Brennan, and Kate ends their friendship. They later make up when Jade apologises. Jade agrees to move in with Kyle at Number 26. During their housewarming party, Kyle and Jade kiss, but Jade is disappointed when Kyle says it did not mean anything. [[Michelle Tran]] (HaiHa Le) moves in to the spare room, but she soon annoys Jade and Kyle. Jade and Kyle have sex and enter into a [[Casual relationship|friends with benefits]] arrangement. Michelle later exposes Jade and Kyle's arrangement to Sonya and Lucas. Kyle then invites [[Rhys Lawson]] ([[Ben Barber]]) to move in. Kyle admits that he has feelings for Jade, but she rejects him. She later has an affair with Malcolm Kennedy, despite knowing he is married.
Jade is touched when Kyle gives her a handmade photo frame for Christmas and she opens up to him about her abusive ex-boyfriend and her commitment issues. The moment is ruined when Kyle learns of her affair with Malcolm. When Jade tells Kyle that she loves him, he walks away and she decides to leave. Just before she boards a coach to Sydney, Kyle finds her and tells her he loves her too. When Jade needs to boost her business, she comes up with the idea for a singles boot camp. Kyle asks Jade to move into his room, but she states that she is not ready although she does love him. Kyle's grandmother, [[Sheila Canning|Sheila]] ([[Colette Mann]]), arrives and make it clear that she does not think Jade is the right girl for Kyle.
Lawyer [[Charlotte McKemmie]] (Meredith Penman) tells Jade that she has some clients who are looking to [[franchising|franchise]] her singles boot camp idea. Sonya's ex-partner, Troy Miller, moves onto Ramsay Street and when Jade confronts him, it emerges that Troy was her abusive ex-boyfriend. Jade explains that she has medical records proving that he hit her and she gives them to Toadie to help his custody case. Jade explains to Sonya and Kyle that she was young and lonely when she fell for Troy. Jade later gives evidence at a mediation meeting. Troy locks Callum in his house and Jade and Sonya manage to get him out, before being locked in themselves. As Troy explains that he just wants to spend time with his son, Jade punches him in the stomach and she and Sonya escape. Troy ends up in hospital with a head injury and he claims that Jade attacked him. The police come to question Jade and she realises that she could face manslaughter charges if Troy dies. Troy regains consciousness and tells the police that Jade was not responsible for his injuries. Troy later dies and Jade admits that she is relieved.
Kate tells Jade that she and Kyle kissed, and a devastated Jade orders Kyle to leave the house. Sheila later apologises to Jade for encouraging Kate to go after Kyle. Jade is touched when Kyle organises a party for her and when one of her clients asks her out, she turns him down as she is not over Kyle. She then admits to Kyle that she still loves him and they get back together. Jade purchases [[Lou Carpenter]]'s ([[Tom Oliver]]) share of Kyle's business and demonstrates her skill in negotiating a lower price from hardware suppliers. Jade learns that some potential investors from the United States want to buy the rights to her singles boot camp franchise, and she decides to go to Los Angeles for six months to sort out the deal. Jade returns home a couple of times to see Kyle and Sonya. She later tells Kyle that she has been offered the chance to stay in Los Angeles for a year and he decides to break up with her, as he cannot leave Erinsborough. Jade thinks about staying, but Kyle tells her that she has to go and Jade leaves for Los Angeles.
==Reception== Upon Jade's introduction, a reporter from the ''[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]'' said she "looks like she's set to cause some trouble."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Soap+stories.-a0247194927|title=Soap stories|date=22 January 2011|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|accessdate=8 May 2011}}</ref> [[Alan Fletcher (actor)|Alan Fletcher]] (who plays [[Karl Kennedy]]) praised Pranita's addition to the cast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/news/11343|title=Alan hails new Neighbours stars after so many left|date=22 December 2010|work=[[What's on TV]]|accessdate=3 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120830025248/http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/news/11343|archivedate=30 August 2012|df=}}</ref> David Barnsby, writing for television magazine ''TV Buzz'', commented that anything is possible with Jade because she is such a "live wire."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Barnsby|first=David|title=Neighbours|work=[[News International|TV Buzz]]|date=19 February 2011|issue=22|pages=30}}</ref> Jaci Stephen of the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' called Jade a "busybody."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1380820/SOAP-WATCH-The-ultimate-insight-weeks-soaps.html|title=The ultimate insight into the week's soaps|last=Stephen|first=Jaci|date=29 April 2011|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref> A writer for [[Holy Soap]] said Jade's most memorable moment was "When she found out Callum's name and realised he was Sonya's son."<ref name="JMHoly"/> Another writer for the website branded her a "serial flirt."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel5.com/shows/neighbours/news/whos-hot-on-gemmas-radar|title=Who's hot on Gemma's radar?|date=5 May 2011|work=[[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]|accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref> Following her one-night stand with Mark, Sarah Ellis of ''[[Inside Soap]]'' said that Jade would be better off if she "set her sights on kind-hearted Kyle."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ellis|first=Sarah|title=Soapbox|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|date=11–17 June 2011|issue=23|pages=97}}</ref> Ellis later wondered how long Kyle and Jade's friends with benefits deal would last until they saw what the rest of the world could.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sarah|first=Ellis|title=Soapbox|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|date=24–30 September 2011|issue=38|pages=97}}</ref> ''Inside Soap'' ran a poll asking viewers to vote for their favourite soap personal trainer and Jade come second, earning 10% of the vote.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Your verdict|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|date=2–8 July 2011|issue=26|pages=97}}</ref>
Tess Larnacraft from ''TV Buzz'' questioned whether Jade and Kyle would ever get together and said she could not "keep watching them skirt around each other for much longer."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Larnacraft|first=Tess|title=Neighbours|work=[[News International|TV Buzz]]|date=20 August 2011|issue=48|pages=13}}</ref> During a feature on soap couples that should be together, another ''Inside Soap'' columnist said Kyle should give up lusting after Kate and realise Jade is "The One."<ref name="please">{{cite journal|title=Oh, please...just get on with it!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|date=24–30 September 2011|issue=38|pages=43}}</ref> They opined that while neither of them have had a relationship for more than twenty four hours, it does put them on an even playing field.<ref name="please"/> Cameron Adams of the ''Herald Sun'' later called Jade and Kyle's relationship "bumby" and he said Jade is an "Alpha female" whose kryptonite is Valentine's Day.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/ipad/tv-dinosaur-cake-and-jamies-haggis/story-fn6bn9st-1226242927347|title=TV: Dinosaur cake and Jamie's haggis|last=Adams|first=Cameron|date=13 January 2012|work=[[Herald Sun]]|accessdate=13 January 2012}}</ref> During Troy's return storyline, the ''Daily Record's'' Sarah Morgan commented "Jade is a woman on a mission - to get Troy out of her family's life once and for all. Although we can understand why she's driven to punch him in the face, we hadn't realised how tough she is as, with one swipe of her fist, he ends up in a coma."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/SOAP+STORIES.-a0297062222|title=Soap stories|last=Morgan|first=Sarah|date=21 July 2012|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|accessdate=25 July 2012}}</ref> Dianne Butler, writing for the ''Herald Sun'', branded the character "Alpha Jade".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/tv-radio/tv-with-di-butler/story-fndx3gil-1226472363903|title=TV with Dianne Butler|last=Butler|first=Dianne|date=11 September 2012|work=[[Herald Sun]]|accessdate=11 September 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Distinguish|John Cleve Green}} {{other persons|John Green}}
{{Infobox scientist |name = John C. Green |image = John C. Green 2017-08-11.jpg |image_size = 200 px |office=Interim President [[The University of Akron]] |term_start=May 1, 2018 |term_end=Present |caption = |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = [[United States|American]] |nationality = |ethnicity = |fields = [[Politics]] |workplaces = [[University of Akron]] |alma_mater = [[Cornell University]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = Research on [[religion and politics]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = |religion = |signature = <!--(filename only)--> |footnotes = }}
'''John C. Green''' is an American [[academic]] who has written numerous books on the relationship between [[religion and politics]].
==Education== John Clifford Green received his [[Bachelors of Arts|B.A.]] degree from the [[University of Colorado System|University of Colorado]] and his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] degree from [[Cornell University]].
==Academic career== Green is a [[scholar]], [[researcher]], and director of the [[Ray C. Bliss Institute of Applied Politics]] at the [[University of Akron]] in [[Ohio]]. He is also a Distinguished Professor of [[Political Science]] at the University of Akron. His area of research is [[religion and politics]] in the U.S. He co-authored the book ''Mormons and American Politics'' with [[Quin Monson]] and [[David E. Campbell (academic)|David E. Campbell]]. He was appointed dean of the Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences by the Board of Trustees on April 19, 2017, after serving as interim dean since October 2015.<ref>http://www.uakron.edu/im/online-newsroom/university-leaders/deans.dot</ref>. Following the resignation of The University of Akron's 17th President, Matthew Wilson, Green was named interim president of the university by the Board of Trustees on April 18th 2018. Green's term as interim president will begin on May 1 2018.
==Honors== Green is a [[Fellow|Senior Fellow]] at the [[Pew Research Center|Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life]].
==Bibliography== *(1991) ''The Bible and the Ballot Box: Religion and Politics in the 1988 Election'' ([[Westview Press]]) ({{ISBN|0813381835}}) *(1993) ''Machine politics, Sound Bites, and Nostalgia: On Studying Political Parties'' ([[University Press of America]]) ({{ISBN|0819188557}}) *(1994) ''Politics, Professionalism, and Power: Modern Party Organization and the Legacy of Ray C. Bliss'' (University Press of America) ({{ISBN|0819193518}}) *(1994) ''Representing Interests and Interest Group Representation'' (University Press of America) ({{ISBN|0819194581}}) *(1996) ''Religion and the Culture Wars: Dispatches From the Front'' (Rowman & Littlefield) ({{ISBN|0847682676}}) *(1997) ''The Bully Pulpit: The Politics of Protestant Clergy'' ([[University Press of Kansas]]) ({{ISBN|0700608680}}) *(1999) ''Financing the 1996 Elections'' (M.E. Sharpe) ({{ISBN|0765603845}}) *(2000) ''Prayers in the Precincts: the Christian Right in the 1998 Elections'' (Georgetown University Press) ({{ISBN|087840774X}}) *(2001) ''The Politics of Ideas: Intellectual Challenges to the Major Parties'' (State University of New York Press) ({{ISBN|0791450449}}) *(2001) ''Superintending Democracy: The Courts and the Political Process'' ([[University of Akron Press]]) ({{ISBN|1884836720}}) *(2002) ''Responsible Partisanship?: The Evolution of American Political Parties Since 1950'' (University Press of Kansas) ({{ISBN|0700612165}}) *(2002) ''Multiparty Politics in America: Prospects and Performance'' (Rowman & Littlefield) ({{ISBN|0742515982}}) *(2003) ''The Christian Right in American Politics: Marching to the Millennium'' ([[Georgetown University Press]]) ({{ISBN|0878403922}}) *(2003) ''The State of the Parties: The Changing Role of Contemporary Party Politics'' (Rowman & Littlefield) ({{ISBN|0742518213}}) *(2003) ''The Test of Time: Coping with Legislative Term Limits'' ([[Lexington Books]]) ({{ISBN|0739104446}}) *(2005) ''The Final Arbiter: The Consequences of Bush v. Gore for Law and Politics'' ([[State University of New York Press]]) ({{ISBN|0791465357}}) *(2006) ''The Values Campaign?: The Christian Right and the 2004 Elections'' (Georgetown University Press) ({{ISBN|1589011090}}) *(2007) ''Fountain of Youth: Strategies and Tactics for Mobilizing America's Young Voters'' ([[Rowman & Littlefield]]) ({{ISBN|0742539652}}) *(2010) ''The Faith Factor: How Religion Influences American Elections'' (Potomac Books Inc.) at [https://www.amazon.com/Faith-Factor-Religion-Influences-Elections/dp/1597974307 Amazon]. {{ISBN|978-1597974301}}<ref name=NYT01>Chozick, Amy, [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/04/us/politics/beck-acts-as-a-bridge-between-romney-and-evangelical-christians.html "Beck Acts as a Bridge Between Romney and Evangelical Christians"], New York ''Times'', November 3, 2012. Retrieved 2012-11-04.</ref>
===Publications=== *(2004) ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20050621001046/http://www.uakron.edu/bliss/docs/Religious_Landscape_2004.pdf American Religious Landscape and Political Attitudes: A Baseline for 2004]''
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090223163111/http://www.uakron.edu/colleges/artsci/depts/polisci/faculty/green.php John Green's Faculty Profile at the University of Akron] *[http://www.uakron.edu/bliss/ Ray C. Bliss Institute of Applied Politics]

revision.text:
{{good article}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox film | name = Kids Can Say No! | image = Kids Can Say No.jpg | alt = See caption | caption = Opening title card | film name = <!--(for non-English films: film's name in its native language)--> | director = Jessica Skippon | producer = Jessica Skippon | writer = Anita Bennett | screenplay = | story = | based on = <!-- {{based on|title of the original work|writer of the original work}} --> | starring = [[Rolf Harris]] | narrator = <!-- or: |narrators = --> | music = [[Peter Alsop]] | cinematography = Deb Ditchburn | editing = | studio = Rolf Harris Video | distributor = Skippon Video | released = October 1985 (United Kingdom)<!-- {{film date|year|month|day|location}} --> | runtime = 20 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = | gross = <!--(please use condensed and rounded values, e.g. "£11.6 million" not "£11,586,221")--> }} '''''Kids Can Say No!''''', stylized as '''''Kids Can Say <u>No</u>''','' is a 1985 [[Cinema of the United Kingdom|British]] [[Short film|short]] [[educational film]] produced and directed by Jessica Skippon and written by Anita Bennett. It is intended to teach children between ages five and eight how to avoid situations where they might be [[Sexual abuse|sexually abused]], how to escape such situations, and how to get help if they are abused. In the film, Australian celebrity [[Rolf Harris]] is in a park with a group of four children and tells them about proper and improper [[physical intimacy]], which he calls "yes" and "no" feelings. The film has four [[role-playing]] scenes in which children encounter [[Pedophilia|paedophiles]], with Harris and the children discussing each scene.
Harris said that he came up with the idea for the film on a 1982 Canadian tour when he saw [[Vancouver]]'s [[Green Thumb Theatre]] production of ''[[Feeling Yes, Feeling No]]'', a play about [[child sexual abuse]]. ''Kids Can Say No!'', released in October 1985 on [[VHS]] in the United Kingdom, was the first British [[children's film]] about sexual abuse and was purchased by police forces, educational institutions, and libraries across Europe. Upon the film's release, ''[[The Times]]'' obtained opinions from four sexual-abuse experts, who unanimously opposed using ''Kids Can Say No!'' or any other film to teach children about the subject. The [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] received a positive response to its 1988 broadcast of ''Kids Can Say No!'' and therefore broadcast it a second time that year. Harris and Skippon collaborated on the 1986 sequel ''Beyond the Scare'', which advises teachers about what to do if a child discloses abuse. Showings of ''Kids Can Say No!'' eventually decreased as VHS became less popular.
''Kids Can Say No!'' resurfaced in 2014, when Harris was prosecuted for twelve counts of [[indecent assault|indecently assaulting]] young girls. The prosecutors found ''Kids Can Say No!'' on [[YouTube]] and wanted to show it at trial to illustrate its unintentional irony, but the film was not [[Admissible evidence|admitted as evidence]]. Harris was found guilty of all counts. During the trial, it was learned that, while Harris was filming ''Kids Can Say No!'', he was in the midst of a [[casual sex]]ual relationship with his daughter Bindi's best friend and, by its release, he had committed nine of the twelve assaults. According to Richard Guilliatt and [[Jacquelin Magnay]] in an article in ''[[The Australian]]'', Harris' campaign against paedophilia in ''Kids Can Say No!'' can "be seen in retrospect as either monumental self-delusion or a sign of deep, self-lacerating guilt".<ref name=Guilliatt/>
==Contents== [[File:Hampstead Heath park (4056628704).jpg|thumb|alt=Hampstead Heath|In ''Kids Can Say No!'', [[Rolf Harris]] sits with four children under a tree in [[Hampstead Heath]] ''(pictured)'' and warns them about [[Pedophilia|paedophiles]].]] In ''Kids Can Say No!'', Australian celebrity [[Rolf Harris]] appears with four children between the ages of seven and eight<ref name=Jefferson>{{Cite news|work=[[Herald Sun]]|title=Rolf Harris in 'No to Child Abuse' Video|author=Jefferson, Andrew|date=26 January 2014|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/law-order/rolf-harris-in-no-to-child-abuse-video/story-fni0fee2-1226810860369|accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref> and warns them about [[Pedophilia|paedophiles]].<ref name=Evans>{{Cite news|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|author=Evans, Martin|title=Rolf Harris Starred in Video Warning Children about Paedophiles|date=30 June 2014|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10935963/Rolf-Harris-starred-in-video-warning-children-about-paedophiles.html|accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref> The film begins with its theme song,<ref name=Pettifor/> "My Body",<ref name=Evans/> which has the chorus "My body's nobody's body but mine. You run your own body. Let me run mine."<ref name=Jefferson/> During the song, children ride a seesaw, skip rope and cycle.<ref name=Moorehead>{{Cite news|work=[[The Times]]|title=Child Abuse: Facing the Unthinkable|author=Moorehead, Caroline|date=2 December 1985|url=https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9UNI002400&an=T000000020051001dhc2015l1&cat=a&ep=ASI|accessdate=25 June 2015}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> Harris sits under a tree in a park with the children—two girls and two boys<ref name=Pettifor/>—and tells them about proper and improper physical intimacy, which he calls "yes" and "no" feelings; a parent's hug is given as an example of a "yes" feeling.<ref name=Walker/> In [[vox populi]] segments, children give other examples of "yes" and "no" feelings; one child says that being tickled by his father is a "yes" feeling, and another says that being squeezed hard is a "no" feeling.<ref name=Wade/> Harris leads the children in a chant of "Go away!" as an exercise in how to respond to "no" feelings.<ref name=Walker>{{Cite news|work=[[The Guardian]]|title=Rolf Harris Fronted Kids Can Say No Film During Period of Assaults|date=30 June 2014|author=Walker, Peter|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/jun/30/rolf-harris-kids-can-say-no-film|accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref> He teaches the children about [[stranger danger]],<ref>{{Cite news|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|title=Pretence of a Sex Predator|author=Radnedge, Aidan|date=1 July 2014|page=1|url=https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9UNI002400&an=METRO00020140701ea710004g&cat=a&ep=ASI|accessdate=21 June 2015}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> and that adults they know can also be a threat.<ref name=Evans/>
The film includes four [[role-playing]] scenes. In the first, a man tells a girl that he will buy her a toy if she goes home with him.<ref name=Pettifor/> In the second, eight-year-old Natasha goes to her friend's house<ref name=Pettifor/> and finds that only her friend's father is home;<ref name=Miranda/> after he intentionally spills water on her clothes, he tells her to take them off.<ref name=Pettifor/> The film cuts to Harris, who says, "She should look him straight in the eye and tell him to stop, go away".<ref name=Pettifor>{{Cite news|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|title=Rolf Harris Guilty: Pervert Fronted Film Warning Kids about Paedophile Danger While Abusing Daughter's Friend|author=Pettifor, Tom|author2=Nick Sommerlad|date=30 June 2014|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/rolf-harris-guilty-pervert-fronted-3791191|accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref> In the third scene, a group of older boys try to lure young children into their "special club";<ref name=Miranda/> they lead one young boy to a secluded, wooded area and try to convince him to remove his clothes.<ref name=Wade/> In the last role-playing scene, Sophie's father offers her a secret bubble bath; afterwards, he tells her not to tell anyone because he would go to jail and it would be her fault.<ref name=Pettifor/>
[[File:Stickfigure800ppx.svg|thumb|upright|alt=A stick figure|Harris draws a [[stick figure]] in the film and says that children who find it difficult to explain where they have been touched can draw a picture and point out the place.]] During and after each of the role-playing scenes, Harris and the children discuss the situation and what the child should do.<ref name=Wade/> Harris tells the children not to be afraid to tell someone if they have been improperly touched, saying, "Some people don't act right with kids, and they need help. You can't protect them from trouble that they themselves have caused, and it's better to say something so that you and the family can get the help you need. You know nothing gets better by keeping quiet about it."<ref name=Walker/> Harris says that, if it is difficult to explain where they have been touched, they can draw a picture or point to the place on a doll.<ref name=Pettifor/> The film ends with "My Body" sung by a group of people including Harris, two police officers, and some children.<ref name=Jefferson/>
==Production== ''Kids Can Say No!'' is a twenty-minute<ref name=Walker/> [[Cinema of the United Kingdom|British]] [[Short film|short]] [[educational film]]<ref name=Law>{{Cite news|work=[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|The Sunday Times]]|title=Brazen Rolf Harris Wanted to Star in WA Child Protection Video in 1980s|author=Law, Peter|author2=Annabel Hennessy|date=6 July 2014|url=http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/western-australia/brazen-rolf-harris-wanted-to-star-in-wa-child-protection-video-in-1980s/story-fnhocxo3-1226978960245|accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> intended to teach children about [[sexual abuse]].<ref name=Walker/> Harris said he was naive about the subject and was motivated to make the film by a female teacher<ref name=Beal/> who told him that, when she spoke to her students about abuse,<ref name=Bingham/> a traumatised girl<ref name=Beal/> ran out of the room; the girl later disclosed that she was being abused by a family member.<ref name=Bingham/> According to Harris, he came up with the idea for the film on a 1982 Canadian tour<ref name=Walker/> when he saw [[Vancouver]]'s [[Green Thumb Theatre]] production of ''[[Feeling Yes, Feeling No]]'', a play about [[child sexual abuse]].<ref name=Wade>{{Cite news|work=[[The Guardian]]|title=The Video Nasty that Children Ought to See: The Child Sex Abuse Film 'Kids Can Say No'|author=Wade, Graham|date=15 October 1985|url=http://www.lexisnexis.com/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=40H4-D5V0-00VY-63D4&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true|accessdate=25 June 2015}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> He was also inspired by a similar Australian production<ref name=Evans/> and a [[Cinema of Sweden|Swedish film]] about two children befriended by a large man on a farm. In an interview, Harris said that, when he saw the Swedish film, he thought the man was going to abuse the children, but that his expectations were incorrect and that "the film was completely innocent; I was not".<ref name=Guilliatt/>
Harris, then host of ''[[Rolf's Cartoon Time]]'', approached the [[National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children]] (NSPCC) and the [[Tavistock and Portman NHS Foundation Trust|Tavistock Clinic]] with his idea about making a film on child [[sexual abuse]]. Both organisations were receptive.<ref name=Guilliatt/> Harris had previous connections with the NSPCC, having appeared in films in 1963 and 1973 promoting the NSPCC League of Pity, and a NSPCC official suggested that he use [[child actor]]s in ''Kids Can Say No!''<ref name=Twomey>{{Cite news|work=[[Daily Express]]|title=Hypocrisy: Rolf Harris Warned of Paedophiles in Children's Charity Video|author=Twomey, John|date=1 June 2014|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/485939/Rolf-Harris-warned-of-paedophiles-in-children-s-charity-video|accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> Harris approached [[Film director|director]] Jessica Skippon, with whom he had made a film about water safety,<ref name=Walker/> and said that he wanted to make ''Kids Can Say No!'' to protect children.<ref name=Evans/> Harris later said that production was hampered by colleagues opposing the idea that children should be told about sexual abuse.<ref name=Guilliatt/>
[[File:Barbara-speake-school-close-up.jpeg|thumb|left|alt=Barbara Speake Stage School|The child actors who appear in ''Kids Can Say No!'' were students at the [[Barbara Speake Stage School]].]]
''Kids Can Say No!'' was made in [[London]] with input from Carolyn Okell Jones, an expert on [[child abuse]],<ref name=Pettifor/> and was filmed on [[Hampstead Heath]] in 1985.<ref name=Guilliatt/> The child actors were students at the [[Barbara Speake Stage School]].<ref name=Peachey/> Skippon directed and produced the film. Funding was difficult because neither the [[Department of Health and Social Security]] nor the [[Home Office]] considered the film under their jurisdiction, and each office referred Skippon to the other.<ref name=Wade/> Childwatch, a [[Charitable organization|charitable organisation]],<ref name=Bracchi>{{Cite news|work=[[Irish Daily Mail]]|title=He Even Led a War Against Other Child Molesters|author=Bracchi, Paul|date=1 July 2014|page=5|url=https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9UNI002400&an=IRDAIM0020140701ea710001f&cat=a&ep=ASI|accessdate=21 June 2015}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> donated £15,000 and technical facilities were provided by Barclays Bank Video.<ref name=Wade/> Harris covered the rest of the film's production costs<ref name=Beal/> and American children's songwriter<ref name=Peachey>{{Cite news|work=[[The Independent]]|title=Rolf Harris Guilty: The Hypocrite Who Warned Children about Paedophiles|author=Peachey, Paul|date=30 June 2014|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/rolf-harris-guilty-the-hypocrite-who-warned-children-about-paedophiles-9574322.html|accessdate=2 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702041329/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/rolf-harris-guilty-the-hypocrite-who-warned-children-about-paedophiles-9574322.html|archivedate=2 July 2015}}</ref> [[Peter Alsop]] wrote the theme song.<ref name=Beal>{{Cite news|work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|title='Filthy Predator': Victim Tells of Star's Depravity|author=Beal, James|date=1 July 2014|url=https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9UNI002400&an=THESUN0020140701ea71000em&cat=a&ep=ASI|accessdate=21 June 2015}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> American Anita Bennett wrote the script, which was reviewed and approved by a NSPCC committee.<ref name=Wade/> ''Kids Can Say No!'' was the second film from Rolf Harris Video, an educational video [[production company]] Harris founded in 1980. In an interview, he said that his role of talking with children about sexual abuse in the film was a natural one because "my track record has made me a believable person. I have never betrayed the kids' trust".<ref name=Guilliatt/>
''Kids Can Say No!'' was the first British [[children's film]] about sexual abuse.<ref name=Bingham>{{Cite news|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|title=Artist to the Queen and Adored by Generations of Viewers|author=Bingham, John|date=1 July 2014|page=2|url=https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9UNI002400&an=DT00000020140701ea710008d&cat=a&ep=ASI|accessdate=24 June 2015}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> The film is intended to teach children between ages five and eight how to avoid situations where they might be abused, how to get out of such situations, and how to get help if they are abused.<ref name=Evans/> Skippon later said that, although the people working on the film tried to keep it from being frightening to children, the task was difficult. She said that the film was not intended for home viewing and that only well-informed adults trained in the subject should present it to children.<ref name=Wade/>
In April 1986, Harris met with [[Western Australia Police]] officials and members of several state-government departments in [[Mount Hawthorn, Western Australia|Mount Hawthorn]] to propose another film for children about how to handle [[sexual predator]]s. Despite Harris' offer to work for free, the officials declined and instead developed a broader campaign on the subject without Harris.<ref name=Law/>
==Release== [[File:Sydney Opera House (9587195189).jpg|thumb|alt=Sydney Opera House|[[Child abuse|Child-abuse]] expert Carolyn Okell Jones presented ''Kids Can Say No!'' at the [[Sydney Opera House]] (''pictured'') in 1986 as part of the sixth [[International Society for the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect|International Congress on Child Abuse and Neglect]].]] ''Kids Can Say No!'' was released in the United Kingdom in October 1985<ref name=Guilliatt/> on [[VHS]]<ref name=Jefferson/> with notes for teachers and two relevant books,<ref name=Wade/> and was distributed by Skippon Video, Skippon's UK-based company.<ref name=Miranda/> Although several other short children's educational films about sexual abuse were on the market in the UK including several also released that year, ''Kids Can Say No!'' was the only British film; the others were made in Australia, Canada and the United States.<ref name=Moorehead/>
In August 1986, Jones presented the film at the [[Sydney Opera House]] in Australia as part of the sixth [[International Society for the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect|International Congress on Child Abuse and Neglect]], the largest conference in the world on child abuse. The 56-year-old Harris, who was chosen to be [[master of ceremonies]] for the three-day conference's opening event because of his celebrity and involvement with the film, told the audience that paedophilia was finally "coming out from under its veil of secrecy".<ref name=Guilliatt>{{Cite news|work=[[The Australian]]|title=The Dark Double Life of Rolf Harris|author=Guilliatt, Richard|author2=[[Jacquelin Magnay]]|date=12 July 2014|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/life/weekend-australian-magazine/the-dark-double-life-of-rolf-harris/story-e6frg8h6-1226981773650|accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref>
Copies of ''Kids Can Say No!'' were purchased by police forces, educational institutions, and libraries across Europe.<ref name=Miranda>{{Cite news|work=[[News.com.au]]|title=Chilling Words from Rolf Harris in a Child Sex Abuse Educational Video, Kids Can Say No!|date=1 July 2014|author=Miranda, Charles|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/chilling-words-from-rolf-harris-in-a-child-sex-abuse-educational-video-kids-can-say-no/story-fncynjr2-1226973208034|accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> The VHS tapes circulated widely in schools and [[rape crisis center]]s in Australia; although showings began to decrease as VHS became less popular,<ref name=Jefferson/> the film was a significant teaching tool.<ref name=Evans/> The [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] received a positive response to its 1988 broadcast of ''Kids Can Say No!'' and therefore broadcast it a second time that year.<ref name=Whelan/>
===Sequel=== After the release of ''Kids Can Say No!'', many teachers who showed the film to their students reported receiving disclosures of abuse. Because many of the teachers said they were unsure of how to deal with the disclosures,<ref name=Guardian/> Harris and Skippon collaborated on the 1986 sequel<ref name=Beal/> ''Beyond the Scare''.<ref name=Guilliatt/> ''Kids Can Say No!'' encourages children to report abuse they experience and ''Beyond the Scare'' advises teachers about what to do if a child makes such a disclosure.<ref name=Guardian/>
''Beyond the Scare'', filmed in a [[North London]] school, consists of role-playing scenes with actual teachers. The film instructs teachers to listen to the child, to discuss the incident with the child's parents and to contact the appropriate authorities. The Tavistock Clinic helped with the film's production, and an expert from the organisation appears on-camera to promote [[child protection]] projects in schools. Although Harris appears in ''Beyond the Scare'', his role is less prominent than in ''Kids Can Say No!''<ref name=Guardian>{{Cite news|work=[[The Guardian]]|title=The Importance of Listening: The Issue of Child Sex Abuse|date=7 October 1986|url=http://www.lexisnexis.com/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=40GH-HB00-00VY-8177&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true|accessdate=25 June 2015}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> and his activism against child abuse ended soon afterwards.<ref name=Guilliatt/>
==Harris' trial== [[File:Rolf Harris.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Rolf Harris|In 2014, Harris was convicted of twelve counts of [[indecent assault]] against four young girls, having committed nine counts before the 1985 release of ''Kids Can Say No!'']] ''Kids Can Say No!'' resurfaced in 2014 when Harris, then 83 years old, was prosecuted for twelve counts of [[indecent assault]] between 1968 and 1986 against four young girls; the youngest was seven years old. The prosecutors found ''Kids Can Say No!'' on [[YouTube]] and wanted to show it at trial for its unintentional irony, but the film was ruled irrelevant to the case and not [[Admissible evidence|admitted as evidence]].<ref name=Miranda/>
After the trial began, Skippon warned media outlets that it was illegal to use the film without written permission.<ref>{{Cite news|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|title=Rolf Harris Starred in Video about Protecting Children in 1980s|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/crime/rolf-harris-starred-in-video-about-protecting-children-in-1985-9573633.html|first=Paul|last=Cheston|date=30 June 2014}}</ref> The director wrote to ''[[The Independent]]'' that no complaints were made against Harris during the making of the film.<ref name=Peachey/> In an article about the allegations against Harris, ''[[The Sunday Telegraph]]'' noted that ''Kids Can Say No!'' was commissioned by the NSPCC;<ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The Sunday Telegraph]]|title=BBC Sex Scandal: A Gifted Entertainer who was Nervous of Groupies|author=Flint, John|date=21 April 2013|page=17|url=https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9UNI002400&an=SUNTEL0020130421e94l00066&cat=a&ep=ASI|accessdate=24 June 2015}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> a NSPCC spokesperson responded, "The film was made independently by Rolf Harris and a film company nearly 30 years ago ... We did not commission it, fund it, make it or distribute it".<ref name=Twomey/>
[[Southwark Crown Court]] found Harris guilty of all twelve counts of indecent assault.<ref name=Miranda/> During the trial, it was learned that, while making ''Kids Can Say No!'', Harris was involved in a [[casual sex]]ual relationship with his daughter Bindi's best friend;<ref name=Walker/> the relationship began when the victim was 13 years old and lasted for 15 years.<ref name=Peachey/> Harris had committed nine of the twelve counts by the film's release,<ref name=Miranda/> including the assault of fifteen-year-old Tonya Lee in London three months before the release.<ref name=Guilliatt/> The first complainant was about the age of the children in ''Kids Can Say No!,''<ref name=Peachey/> although the conviction related to this count was quashed in 2017.<ref name=appeal>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-42012064|title=Rolf Harris indecent assault conviction overturned|work=BBC News|date=16 November 2017|accessdate=21 December 2017}}</ref> The last assault of which Harris was convicted occurred several weeks after his meeting with officials in Western Australia to propose another film about child sexual abuse.<ref name=Law/> A former child actor from the Barbara Speake Stage School who appeared in ''Kids Can Say No!'' said that Harris' behavior with older girls at the school made Harris' eventual arrest unsurprising.<ref name=Peachey/>
==Reception== Reviews of ''Kids Can Say No!'' have generally been negative, with initial reviews doubting the benefit of showing the film to children and later reviews focusing on Harris' hypocrisy. In a 1985 ''[[The Times|Times]]'' review, Caroline Moorehead writes that the film's avoidance of an explicit discussion of sexual abuse was both a requirement and the film's greatest weakness. According to Moorehead, an explicit discussion might have terrified children and prevented parents from consenting to their children's viewing of the film; however, its oblique approach prevents children from understanding the issue. She calls the film's theme song "catchy, one of those irritating snatches of music that is hard to forget".<ref name=Moorehead/>
''The Times'' obtained opinions from four sexual-abuse experts, who unanimously opposed using ''Kids Can Say No!'' or any other film to teach children about the subject. [[Northampton]] [[social work]]er Helen Kenward said that she would not show the film to children. [[Psychiatrist]] Brendan McCarthy called it simplistic. According to teacher Clare Rankin, children under five would not understand the film. [[Physician]] Paula Drummond was concerned that it might inspire children to falsely accuse adults they disliked, although McCarthy said that children were unlikely to make false abuse accusations. McCarthy was especially critical of the film, calling it "no clearer to a child than the Gorbachev-Reagan talks".<ref name=Moorehead/> Moorehead summarised the experts' comments as suggesting that ''Kids Can Say No!'' is "muddling, evasive and pussy-footed, best not for children at all, but as ... aids for parents and professional workers to alert them to paedophilia and incest".<ref name=Moorehead/>
In a 1988 ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald|Sydney Morning Herald]]'' review, Judith Whelan writes that Harris is more serious in the film than he was when performing "[[Jake the Peg]]". According to Whelan, the film "would best be seen by children in a group, with an adult (teacher or parent) nearby who could encourage discussion after the show or answer children's questions during it".<ref name=Whelan>{{Cite news|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|title=Saying 'No' is a Child's First Defence|author=Whelan, Judith|date=21 November 1988|page=6|url=https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9UNI002400&an=smhh000020011117dkbl0214s&cat=a&ep=ASI|accessdate=24 June 2015}} {{Subscription required}}</ref>
When ''Kids Can Say No!'' resurfaced in 2014, Peter Walker wrote in ''[[The Guardian]]'' that the film "illustrates with grim eloquence, in retrospect, the prosecution notion that [Harris] was a man of two distinct sides: the avuncular and trustworthy public figure, and lurking behind, the groper and abuser".<ref name=Walker/> Walker notes that the scene in which a man assaults his child's friend mirrors what Harris did to his daughter's best friend, and that the closing sequence has "an accidental resonance that would only emerge more than 25 years later" because of the two police officers behind Harris.<ref name=Walker/>
According to Richard Guilliatt and [[Jacquelin Magnay]] in an article in ''[[The Australian]]'', Harris' campaign against paedophilia in ''Kids Can Say No!'' can "be seen in retrospect as either monumental self-delusion or a sign of deep, self-lacerating guilt".<ref name=Guilliatt/> NSPCC chief executive officer [[Peter Wanless]] appeared on ''[[Good Morning Britain (2014 TV programme)|Good Morning Britain]]'' saying that Harris' appearance in the film was hypocritical.<ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The Independent]]|title=Rolf Harris Guilty: Abuse Victim Wrote to the Queen to Warn Her as the Presenter Painted Monarch's Portrait|first=Jenn|last=Selby|date=1 July 2014|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/rolf-harris-guilty-victim-wrote-to-the-queen-to-warn-her-as-the-presenter-painted-her-portrait-9575140.html}}</ref> In an ''[[Irish Daily Mail]]'' article, Paul Bracchi writes that Harris' work on ''Kids Can Say No!'' at the same time that he was abusing girls was "one of the most sickening examples [of] hiding in plain sight".<ref name=Bracchi/> In 2014, theme composer Peter Alsop said that Harris may have used the film to [[Child grooming|groom children]] because it encouraged trust by parents.<ref name=Beal/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{IMDb title|3840582|Kids Can Say No!}}
